PREFACE
This City Code of the City of Sandpoint, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to and including ordinance 1360, passed December 5, 2018.
Ordinances of the City adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this City Code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent
therewith. Consult the City office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the Code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
Sterling Codifiers
Coeur d'Alene, Idaho
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 1050
AN ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF SANDPOINT, BONNER COUNTY, IDAHO, ADOPTING THE CITY CODE OF SANDPOINT, IDAHO, FOR REVISING,
CODIFYING AND COMPILING THE GENERAL ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF SANDPOINT AS CODIFIED BY STERLING CODIFIERS THROUGH
AND INCLUDING CITY OF SANDPOINT ORDINANCE NO. 1044, PROVIDING PENALTIES FOR UNLAWFUL ALTERATION OR MODIFICATION OF
THE CODE, AND PROVIDING FOR THE PUBLICATION OF THIS ORDINANCE.
Be it ordained by the Mayor and City Council of the City of Sandpoint, as follows, to-wit:
Whereas, provisions of Title 50, Chapter 9 Idaho Code authorize publication of compiled ordinances of a city by compilation and codification, and
Whereas, it is sound practice to enact a periodic codification ordinance to establish a baseline for further codification efforts.
SECTION 1: Ordinance No. 773 adopted the official City Code of the City of Sandpoint, together with a method of perpetual codification by Sterling
Codifiers, Inc. on the 22nd day of February, 1983. Subsequent to such adoption, the city council has enacted ordinances through the ordinance number
#1044, a summary of which was published on the 2nd day of November, 2000. This ordinance hereby adopts the codification compiled by Sterling
Codifiers incorporating all ordinances enacted up to and including Ordinance #1044. By such adoption the City council also confirms, approves and reenacts
all previously adopted ordinance provisions and ordinance summaries of the City of Sandpoint, up to and inclusive of Ordinance #1044, as such
have been compiled by Sterling Codifiers. A copy of the compilation existing at the time of approval of this ordinance shall be filed and maintained with this
ordinance to serve as a codification reference from the effective date of Ordinance #1044, going forward.
SECTION 2: The codification completed by Sterling Codifiers through ordinance #1044 enacted on the 18th day of October, 2000, constitutes a
compilation of all ordinances of a general nature, together with subsequent changes made to said ordinances, under the direction of the governing body of
the City. It shall be accepted in all courts as the official Code and law of the City as enacted by the Mayor and City Council.
SECTION 3: All ordinances of a general nature included in this official City Code shall be considered as a continuation of said ordinance provision and the
fact that some provisions have been deliberately eliminated by the governing body shall not serve to cause any interruption in the continuous effectiveness
of ordinances included in said official City Code. All ordinances of a special nature, such as tax levy ordinances, bond ordinances, franchises, vacating
ordinances and annexation ordinances shall continue in full force and effect unless specifically repealed or amended by a provision of the City Code. Such
ordinances are not intended to be included in the official City Code.
SECTION 4: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such Code, or to
insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City to be
misrepresented thereby.
Any person, firm or corporation violating this Section shall be punished as provided in Section 1-4-1 of the City Code of Sandpoint, Idaho.
SECTION 5: All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith, are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed.
SECTION 6: This Ordinance and this Code adopted by the same shall be in full force and effect upon publication of this Ordinance according to law in the
Bonner County Sandpoint Daily Bee, a newspaper of general distribution in the City of Sandpoint, Idaho, and hereby declared to be the official newspaper
for the publication of this Ordinance.
Passed and adopted as an ordinance of the City of Sandpoint, Idaho, at a special session of the Sandpoint City Council on the 7th day of March, 2001.
Title 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
Chapter 1
OFFICIAL MUNICIPAL CODE
1-1-1: TITLE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 2/303
Upon adoption by the City Council, this Code is hereby declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official Code of the City of Sandpoint. This Code
shall be known and cited as the SANDPOINT CODE, and it is hereby published by authority of the City Council and shall be kept up to date as provided in
Section 1-1-3 of this Chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number,
its appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause, relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to this
Code by title in any legal documents. (1983 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of this State
as the ordinances of the City of general and permanent effect. (1983 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending the Code shall set forth the title, chapter and section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Code. All such amendments
or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the codifiers and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in its proper place
in each copy of this Code. (1983 Code)
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATION:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface in any way any section or any page of this Code in such a manner that the
meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Upon passage of amending ordinances by the City Council, the replacement pages provided
by the codifiers shall be properly inserted in the official copies maintained in the City Clerk's office and other City offices in a timely manner and under the
direction and supervision of the City Clerk. Any person having in his custody an official copy of the City Code shall make every effort to maintain the Code
in an up to date and efficient manner in cooperation with the City Clerk. Said Code books, while in actual possession of officials and other interested
persons, shall be and remain the property of the City and shall be returned to the office of the Clerk when directed to do so by the Clerk. (1983 Code)
Chapter 2
SAVING CLAUSE
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the City passed prior to the adoption of this Code are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this Code, and the
following ordinances which are not hereby repealed:
A. Appropriation ordinances; namely, that appropriation ordinance currently in effect at the time of adoption hereof, Ordinance 766. As each new
appropriation ordinance is adopted annually, it shall supersede any previous appropriation ordinance.
B. Franchise ordinances; namely, Ordinances 16 and 362, both to Spokane International Railroad; 419 and 436, both to Northern Lights, Inc.; 428 and
637, both for cable television; 606 to Pacific Power and Light Company and 607 to Washington Water Power Company.
C. Ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places; namely, Ordinances 4, 6, 7, 8, 9, 14, 18, 20, 21, 23, 25, 32, 46, 131,
176, 215, 229, 253, 267, 278, 289, 306, 325, 352, 378, 386, 389, 391, 411, 682, 701, 702 and 767.
D. Improvement district ordinances; namely, Ordinances 429 and 433 for L.I.D. 25; and Ordinances 651, 656, 670, 671, 672, 677, 706 and 717 for L.I.D.
26.
E. Bond ordinances; namely, Ordinances 392, 358, 423 and 660. (1983 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall be
repealed by virtue of the adoption of this Code excepting as this Code may contain provisions for such matters, in which case this Code shall be
considered as amending such ordinance or ordinances in respect to such provisions only. (1983 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the City herein
repealed; nor shall this Chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the liability of
any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the City under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the adoption of this
Code. (1983 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 3/303
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code or any part thereof is for any reason held to be unconstitutional
or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining portions of this
Code, or any part thereof. The City Council hereby declares that it would have passed each section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause
or phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared
unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective. (1983 Code)
Chapter 3
DEFINITIONS
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this code importing the plural number is used in describing or referring to any matters, parties or persons, any single
matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included, although distributive words may not have been used.
When any subject matter, party or person is referred to in this code by words importing the singular number only, or the masculine gender, several matters,
parties or persons and females as well as males and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included; provided, that these rules of construction shall not
be applied to any section of this code which contains any express provision excluding such construction or where the subject matter or context may be
repugnant thereto.
The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the city has been changed in the content of this code to "title", "chapter", "section" and/or "subsection"
or words of like import for organizational and clarification purposes only.
The word "day" shall mean any twenty four (24) hour period from one twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight to the next. All use of the word "day" or "days" in this
code shall be consecutive or calendar days unless otherwise declared to be "working" days.
"Working day" shall be days the city clerk's office is open to conduct city business. Any deadline that falls on a Saturday, Sunday or other day when the
city clerk's office is closed shall be extended to five o'clock (5:00) P.M. the following working day. (Ord. 1274, 7-18-2012)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS, GENERAL:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have such meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such
meaning repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another.
CITY: The city of Sandpoint, county of Bonner, state of Idaho.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city employee by title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the
city of Sandpoint".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the city for the carrying on of a business, profession or occupation.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR: When a crime punishable by imprisonment in the state prison is also punishable by fine or imprisonment in a county jail, in the discretion
of the court, it shall be deemed a misdemeanor for all purposes after a judgment imposing a punishment other than imprisonment in the state prison.
Wherever the words "misdemeanor", "petty misdemeanor" or "violation" are used in this code, these terms or any of them shall be construed to mean
misdemeanor and shall be punished, unless otherwise provided under section 1-4-1 of this title.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the inhabitants of the city; or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a hazard
to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or to the community.
OCCUPANT: The word "occupant" as applied to a building or land shall include any person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land
whether alone or with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any act required by the provisions of this code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city officer by title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Sandpoint".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: The word "owner" as applied to a building or land shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole
or of a part of such building or land.
PERSON: Any public or private corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization, government or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a
natural person.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods, chattels, effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by
which any pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged, transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every
right or interest therein.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 4/303
PUBLIC SAFETY DIRECTOR: The public safety director shall be the fire department chief and the police department chief and shall have charge,
supervision, and direction over all officers and employees assigned to the fire department and the police department. Whenever a person has been
appointed as public safety director, the term "public safety director" shall be synonymous with fire chief and police chief as those terms are found within
this code.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small quantities
direct to the consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other property.
STREET: Shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: The word "tenant" as applied to a building or land shall include any person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether
alone or with others.
WHOLESALER: The terms "wholesaler" and "wholesale dealer" as used in this code, unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate to
the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: The words "written" or "in writing" may include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters, but when the
written signature of any person is required by law to any official or public writing or bond required by law, it shall be in the proper handwriting of such
person, or in case he is unable to write, by his proper mark. (1983 Code; amd. Ord. 997, 2-19-1997)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of the code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or taken
to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any division or
section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted.
(1983 Code)
Chapter 4
GENERAL PENALTY
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
Except in cases where a different punishment is prescribed in this code, every offense declared to be a misdemeanor is punishable by a fine not
exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense, or imprisonment in a county jail not to exceed six (6) months, or by both such fine and
imprisonment1.
Except in cases where a different punishment is prescribed in this code, every offense declared to be an infraction is punishable by a penalty not
exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) and no imprisonment. (Ord. 1183, 10-17-2007)
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of this code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this code where a duty is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any action which is of a
continuing nature is forbidden or is declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed
upon each day such duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise specifically provided in this code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect under
which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced. Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do
any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this code and there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the
provisions of this chapter shall apply. (1983 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or
penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intent of the council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is specifically
and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (1983 Code)
Chapter 5
MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL
1-5-1: MEETINGS OF THE COUNCIL:
A. Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the city council shall be held on the first and third Wednesdays of each and every month or, if said Wednesday
is a holiday, on the next day following the first or third Wednesday which is not a holiday. (Ord. 1271, 6-20-2012)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 5/303
B. Special Meetings: Special meetings may be held at the call of the mayor by serving notice on each member of the city council in writing stating the
object of said meeting as provided in Idaho Code 50-604. A majority of the members of the full council shall have the power to call special meetings of
the city council by serving notice in writing on all members of the city council stating the object of the meeting as provided in section 50-706 of the
Idaho Code. The city clerk shall record the proceedings at all special meetings in the city council meeting records. (Ord. 764, 4-19-1982)
C. Time Of Meetings; Open To The Public: All regular meetings shall convene promptly at five thirty o'clock (5:30) P.M. at the city hall (or at another
location when notice of the other location is posted at city hall at least 24 hours in advance of the meeting) and all meetings, regular or special, shall be
open to the public, except executive sessions as provided in Idaho Code title 74, chapter 2. (Ord. 1315, 7-1-2015)
1-5-2: RULES AND ORDER OF BUSINESS:
A. Quorum: A quorum shall consist of a majority of the full council and all matters coming before the city council shall be decided by a majority of those
present unless otherwise provided by law.
B. Presiding Officer: The presiding officer of the city council shall be the mayor or in the absence of the mayor, the president of the council. In the absence
of both the mayor and the president of the council, the clerk shall call the council to order and call the roll. If there is a quorum present, the council shall
then elect, by majority vote, a chairperson to act until the arrival of the mayor or president of the council. The presiding officer shall preserve strict order
and decorum at all regular and special meetings of the city council. (Ord. 764, 4-19-1982)
C. Roll Call: Before proceeding with the business of the city council, the mayor shall determine and announce who is present and who is absent and the
names of those present and absent shall be entered into the minutes by the city clerk. (Ord. 1147, 3-15-2006)
D. Functions Of Mayor:
1. Mayor's Voting Restricted: The mayor shall have a vote at city council meetings only when the council is equally divided and when not otherwise
prohibited by law. (Ord. 764, 4-19-1982)
2. Veto Power Of Mayor: The mayor shall have the power to veto or sign any ordinance passed by the city council. If the mayor shall veto an ordinance,
said veto must be in writing within ten (10) working days and notice be given by the city clerk to all council members in writing within five (5) working
days thereafter. The council may pass a vetoed ordinance by a vote of one-half (1/2) plus one of the members of the full council. Should the mayor
neglect or refuse to sign an ordinance and return it to the city council at the next regular city council meeting, the same shall become law without the
mayor's signature upon proper publication. (Ord. 1274, 7-18-2012)
E. Attendance Requirement: (Rep. by Ord. 1147, 3-15-2006)
F. Order Of Business: The order of business at the city council meetings shall be as follows:
1. Call to order.
2. Roll call.
3. Opening ceremonies.
4. Announcements.
5. Public forum.
6. Consent calendar.
7. Old business.
8. New business.
9. Miscellaneous.
10. Adjournment. (Ord. 1147, 3-15-2006)
G. Speaking And Addressing The Council: (Rep. by Ord. 1147, 3-15-2006)
H. Motions, Procedure:
1. Motions shall be reduced to writing when required by the presiding officer of the city council or any member of the city council. All resolutions and
ordinances shall be in writing at the time considered and voted upon.
2. Motions to reconsider must be by a member who voted with the majority previously and must be presented at the same or next succeeding meeting
of the city council.
3. Motions to lay any matter on the table shall be first in order and on all questions, the last amendment, the most distant day and the largest sum shall
be first put to vote.
4. A motion for adjournment shall always be in order.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 6/303
I. Recording Of Votes: Whenever it shall be required by one or more members, the affirmative and negative votes shall be recorded. Any member may call
for a division on the question so that two (2) or more parts of a motion may be considered and voted upon as separate questions.
J. Questions Of Order: All questions of order shall be decided by the presiding officer of the city council with the right of appeal to the council by any
member allegedly aggrieved.
K. Altering Rules: The rules of the council may be temporarily altered, amended or suspended by unanimous vote of the members present constituting a
quorum of the full council.
L. Reports To Council: The chairperson of each respective committee or the council member acting in his place, shall submit or make all reports to the
council when so requested by the presiding officer or any member of the council.
M. Ordinance Passage Procedure:
1. Ordinances shall be read on three (3) different days, two (2) readings of which may be by title only and one reading shall be in full. No ordinance or
resolution of a permanent nature shall be adopted at the meeting at which it is introduced unless the rules concerning reading and adoption of
ordinances and resolutions of a permanent nature on separate days be suspended by a vote of at least one-half (1/2) plus one of the full council. Any
such vote on a motion to suspend the rules and a vote on the motion to adopt the ordinance or resolution under suspension of rules shall be by roll
call and so recorded in the minutes.
2. The passage of an ordinance or resolution to enter a contract shall be by roll call of the city council with the affirmative and negative vote of each
council member being duly recorded in the minutes.
3. All ordinances, resolutions or propositions submitted to the council which require the expenditure of public monies shall lie over until the next regular
council meeting; provided, however, that such ordinances, resolutions or propositions may be considered earlier by unanimous consent of the
members present constituting a quorum of the full council; and, provided further, that this rule shall not apply to current expenses, contracts
previously made or regular salaries or wages of employees of the city. (Ord. 764, 4-19-1982)
N. Rules Of Order: The parliamentary procedure of city council meetings shall be governed by "Parliamentary Procedure Made Easier", latest edition,
published by Washington State University, a copy of which is on file in the city clerk's office. (Ord. 1271, 6-20-2012)
1-5-3: COUNCIL COMMITTEES:
There shall be no permanent standing city council committees. (Ord. 1271, 6-20-2012)
Chapter 6
MUNICIPAL OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
1-6-1: APPOINTIVE CITY OFFICERS:
The designated appointed officers and officials of the city are as follows:

City administrator
City attorney
City clerk
City treasurer
Fire chief
Parks and recreation director
Planning director
Public works director
Said officials and officers shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council in accordance with Idaho Code. (Ord. 1318, 10-21-2015)
1-6-2: TERMS OF OFFICERS:
Each and every appointive officer of the city enumerated in section 1-6-1 of this chapter shall serve at the discretion and pleasure of the mayor and city
council. Said officer or official may be terminated at any time by the mayor for any cause by him deemed sufficient. Such removal shall be confirmed by the
affirmative vote of one-half (1/2) plus one of the members of the full council; provided, however, that the city council, by the unanimous vote of all its
members, may, upon its own initiative, remove any appointive officer1. (Ord. 755, 10-19-1981; amd. 1983 Code)
1-6-3: COMPENSATION OF MUNICIPAL OFFICERS:
The compensation of the officers hereinafter named for the city is established as follows:
Mayor $12,000.00 per annum, payable monthly

Council member 3,300.00 per annum, payable monthly2

Should the mayor have use of a city vehicle, it will be for official business only. The vehicle is to be parked at city hall overnight and during weekends. Said
vehicle will not be for personal use. (Ord. 1029, 8-25-1999; amd. Ord. 1285, 8-7-2013)
1-6-4: ZONING ENFORCEMENT OFFICER:
A. Office Created: There is hereby created and defined an official of the city, hereafter referred to as the enforcement officer of the city.
B. Duties: The duties of the enforcement officer of the city shall include the following:
1. Review all building permits for zoning compliance.
2. Perform a field survey of the city from a schedule such that total review and survey of all property shall be had at least once during every five (5)
year period. Said survey and review shall be used to maintain and assure a current, up to date land use map.
3. Investigate all complaints concerning zoning and/or land use violations.
4. Maintain a comprehensive file on all such complaints received and the ultimate action and process taken. (Ord. 718, 5-7-1980)
C. Enforcement Procedure: The enforcement procedure applicable for use by the enforcing officer shall be as follows:
1. Building Permits:
a. Building permit applications shall be submitted to the building inspector.
b. Building permit applications shall then be referred to the enforcing officer for review to determine compliance with the applicable and existing
zoning codes. This review shall be completed within five (5) working days following referral. (Ord. 1274, 7-18-2012)
c. If the plans as submitted are not satisfactory, a memorandum stating the reasons and causes of noncompliance shall be attached to the
application, and a copy of such memorandum shall be mailed to the applicant by certified mail with a return receipt requested.
d. If the plans are in compliance with the zoning code, the enforcement officer shall initial the appropriate block on the building application indicating
compliance.
2. Investigation Of Complaints: Procedure for the investigation of complaints received by the enforcing officer shall be as follows:
a. Upon the receipt of a complaint involving a possible zoning violation, the enforcing officer or his deputy shall within thirty (30) days investigate the
complaint and file a written report with the mayor's office. A copy of the complaint and report shall be maintained on file by the enforcing officer.
b. Upon the direction of the mayor's office, the enforcing officer shall notify the owner of the property concerned within fifteen (15) days of the
existence of the alleged violation. Further, the notice to the owner shall request correction, justification, prior authorization or a plan of correction
submitted to the enforcement officer within thirty (30) days of the notification.
c. The owner shall thereafter submit proof of authorization, prior compliance or a written plan for the correction of the violation within said thirty (30)
day period. Any plan or correction of violation shall include final correction within a reasonable time period.
d. If no response is received from the owner, he shall then be notified that the city will pursue the matter with affirmative legal action within the
following fifteen (15) days.
e. The mayor shall then review the record and within seven (7) days direct the legal department of the city to take affirmative legal action within thirty
(30) days to stop the work, obtain restraining orders or injunctions, obtain revocation of the certificate of occupancy or any other applicable and
available remedy.
D. Additional Powers And Duties: The enforcing officer is hereby empowered to perform all tasks, work assignments, investigations, reviews and
evaluations necessary and incumbent to the performance of his duties and responsibilities set forth herein. The records, reports, documents and
information resulting from the performance of the duties of the enforcing officer shall be maintained on file by the enforcing officer at city hall. All such
documents shall be the records and property of the city. (Ord. 718, 5-7-1980)
Chapter 7
CODE OF ETHICS
1-7-1: DECLARATION OF POLICY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 8/303
The public judges its government by the way public officials and employees conduct themselves in the post to which they have been elected or appointed.
The people have a right to expect that every public official and employee will conduct himself in a manner that will tend to preserve the public confidence in
and respect for the government he represents. Such confidence and respect can best be promoted if every public official and employee, whether paid or
unpaid and whether elected or appointed, will uniformly:
A. Treat all citizens with courtesy, impartiality, fairness and equality under the law; and,
B. Avoid both actual and potential conflicts between their private self interest and the public interest.
To help public officials and employees achieve this goal, is the objective of this code of ethics. (Ord. 761, 1-18-1982)
1-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
The terms used in this code of ethics are hereby defined as follows:
FINANCIAL INTEREST: Any interest which shall yield, directly or indirectly, a monetary or other material benefit (other than the duly authorized salary or
compensation for his services to the City) to the official or employee or to any person employing or retaining the services of the official or employee.
OFFICIAL OR EMPLOYEE: Any person elected or appointed to or employed or retained by any public office or public body in the City, whether paid or
unpaid and whether part-time or full-time.
PERSON: Any person, firm, association, group, partnership or corporation or combination thereof.
PERSONAL INTEREST: Any interest arising from blood or marriage relationships or from close business or political association, whether or not any
financial interest is involved.
PUBLIC BODY: Any agency, board, body, commission, committee, department or office of the City of Sandpoint. (Ord. 761, 1-18-1982)
1-7-3: FAIR AND EQUAL TREATMENT:
A. Impartiality: No official or employee shall grant or make available to any person any consideration, treatment, advantage or favor beyond that which is
the general practice to grant or make available to the public at large.
B. Use Of Public Property: No official or employee shall request, use or permit the use of any publicly owned or publicly supported property, vehicle,
equipment, labor or service for the personal convenience or the private advantage of himself or any other person. This rule shall not be deemed to
prohibit any official or employee from requesting, using or permitting the use of such publicly owned or publicly supplied property, vehicle, equipment,
material, labor or service which it is the general practice to make available to the public at large or which are provided as a matter of stated public
policy for the use of officials and employees in the conduct of official business. (Ord. 761, 1-18-1982)
1-7-4: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
A. Financial Or Personal Interest: No official or employee, either on his own behalf or on behalf of any other person, shall have any financial or personal
interest in any business or transaction with the public body unless he shall first make full public disclosure of the nature and extent of such interest.
B. Disclosure And Disqualification: Whenever the performance of his official duties shall require any official or employee to deliberate and vote on any
matter involving his financial or personal interest, he shall publicly disclose the nature and extent of such interest and disqualify himself from
participating in the deliberation as well as in the voting.
C. Incompatible Employment: No official or employee shall engage in private employment with or render services for any private person who has business
transactions with any public body unless he shall first make full public disclosure of the nature and extent of such employment or services.
D. Representation Of Private Persons: No official or employee shall appear on behalf of any private person other than himself before any public body in
the city.
E. Gifts And Favors: No official or employee shall accept any gift, whether in the form of money, thing, favor, loan or promise, that would not be offered or
given to him if he were not an official or employee of the city.
F. Confidential Information: No official or employee shall, without prior formal authorization of the public body having jurisdiction, disclose any confidential
information concerning any other official or employee or any other person or any property or governmental affairs of the city, whether or not this shall
involve disclosure. No official or employee shall use or permit the use of any such confidential information to advance the financial or personal interest
of himself or any other person. (Ord. 761, 1-18-1982)
G. Nepotism: No elected official shall appoint or vote for appointment of any person related by blood or marriage to any clerkship, office position,
employment or duty when the salary, wages, pay or compensation is to be paid out of public funds as provided in Idaho Code title 74, chapter 4. (Ord.
1315, 7-1-2015)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 9/303
1-7-5: INTERPRETATION:
Any interpretation of this chapter and advisory opinion shall be made in the following manner:
A. Any city council member may question actions of any other public official by submission of facts to the city council as a whole, which facts shall be
reduced to writing by the city clerk. The defending public official shall be given an opportunity to respond immediately to any question or may request
continuance of a presentation and decision on such matter until the following regularly scheduled city council meeting. The opinion of a majority of the
city council hearing the questioned matter shall be the decision of the council of the whole. Such decision shall be advisory only.
B. Any voter registered to vote within the city limits of the city may raise a question under this chapter by setting forth the facts in writing and delivering
them to the mayor. The mayor shall immediately cause copies of said writing to be delivered to each member of the city council and shall cause the
matter to be brought before the city council at the next regularly scheduled city council meeting. The city council shall resolve the question through a
majority vote of the council hearing the matter at the regular public meeting of the city council at which said question is reported by the mayor, unless
the defending public official or employee requests that the matter be continued until the next subsequent regular public meeting of the city council.
C. In all cases the mayor shall have the right to vote only in the event that it is necessary to break a tie. In the event that the mayor shall be the questioned
public official, the president of the council or if the president of the council is not present, such other member of the city council as a majority of those
council members present shall designate, shall preside over that portion of the city council meeting or meetings which concerns the question or charge
by either a city council member or registered voter.
D. The city clerk shall retain a record of the hearing on each such matter thus brought before the city council including a disposition of the matter and the
decision of a majority of the council hearing the question. (Ord. 761, 1-18-1982)
1-7-6: PENALTY:
Any public official who shall intentionally violate the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine of not more
than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or imprisonment in the county jail not to exceed six (6) months, or both. Any employee who shall intentionally violate
the provisions of this Chapter shall be subject to appropriate action for censure, suspension or removal from employment. In addition, the conviction of any
public official of any violation of this Chapter shall be prima facie evidence that said public official has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude
and/or an offense involving a violation of his oath of office. (Ord. 761, 1-18-1982; 1983 Code)
Chapter 8
INITIATIVE AND REFERENDUM
1-8-1: CREATION OF RIGHT:
The people of the city shall have the right to enact ordinances through the initiative process, and to repeal ordinances through the referendum process
according to the procedure set forth below. (Ord. 636, 3-19-1979)
1-8-2: PETITIONS FOR INITIATIVE OR REFERENDUM:
A. Conform To State Statute: All city initiative and referendum elections shall be conducted in conformity with chapter 18 of title 34, Idaho Code, and
chapter 5 of title 50, Idaho Code.
B. Number Of Petitioners Required: To enact an ordinance by initiative or to repeal an ordinance by referendum, there shall be attached or appended to
the petition the signatures of the legal voters of the city equal to at least twenty percent (20%) of the total number of electors who cast votes in the last
general election in the city.
C. Time For Filing Referendum Petitions: Petitions with the requisite number of signatures attached thereto shall be filed with the county clerk not less than
sixty (60) days following the final adoption of the ordinance which is subject to the referendum.
D. Time For Filing Initiative Petitions: Petitions shall be filed with the county clerk eighteen (18) months from the date petitioner received the official ballot
title from the county clerk or April 30 of the year of the next general election, whichever occurs earlier.
E. Requirements For Signature, Verification Of Valid Petition, Printing Of Petitions, And Time Limits: Referendum and initiative petitions shall conform with
requirements for signature, verification of valid petition, printing of petitions, and time limits as provided in Idaho Code section 34-1801 et seq. (Ord.
1273, 7-18-2012)
1-8-3: ELECTIONS:
Special elections shall be conducted pursuant to section 34-106 of Idaho Code. (Ord. 1273, 7-18-2012)
1-8-4: INITIATIVE REQUIRED FOR CONSOLIDATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 10/303
Before the council may adopt an ordinance consolidating the city's fire protection service with any fire protection district pursuant to Idaho Code chapter 14
title 31 as it is now written or as it may subsequently be amended, the city council shall be required to cause there to be a vote of the citizens of Sandpoint,
whether at a regular or special election, on an initiative which sets forth facts in favor of or opposed to such an action. (Ord. 995, 11-20-1996)
Chapter 9
ELECTION PRECINCTS
1-9-1: PRECINCTS ESTABLISHED:
A. Election Precincts: There shall be one voting and election precinct within the corporate limits of the city for all city elections which shall encompass the
entire corporate city limits.
B. Designated Places And Persons: Voting, polling and registration places and persons shall be designated by resolution of the city council for all
elections, voting and registrations for voting within the city. (Ord. 1058, 8-15-2001)
Chapter 10
MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
1-10-1: CORPORATE LIMITS; MAP:
There are hereby defined, as hereinafter described and depicted, corporate limits and boundaries for the Municipal corporation of the City of Sandpoint,
Bonner County, Idaho. Said corporate limits and boundaries are depicted, pictured and set forth on the map adopted by reference and made a part hereof.
Said map is hereby adopted as a part hereof and declared to be a depiction of the legal corporate limits of the City, and said boundaries are further
described by written work setting forth the legal and geographic description of the outer property boundary line encompassing and constituting the outer
limits of the corporate boundary of the City. Said legal written description of said boundary line and corporate limit line shall be certified by the Mayor and
attested to by the City Clerk thereon and at least three (3) certified copies of the same shall be on file in the office of the City Clerk and shall be open for
public inspection and dissemination and copies of the same shall be provided to any member of the public upon request.
The map depicting the boundary and corporate limits of the City, and made a part hereof and above referenced, shall likewise be certified by the Mayor
and attested to by the City Clerk upon its adoption. Thereafter said map shall be referred to as the official map depicting the corporate limits of the City,
until and unless modified or amended by appropriate ordinance. Said map shall, with this Section, upon adoption be filed and recorded with the Recorder
of Bonner County, Idaho and become a part of the official records of Bonner County, Idaho and of the official records of the City. Copies of the certified
map shall be made available to the general public and all interested persons and certified copies of the same shall be on file in the office of the City Clerk.
All real property located within and lying within the boundary limits and boundary lines as depicted on said official map, if previously unannexed into the
City, be and the same is hereby annexed to and within the City as contiguous, adjacent and adjoining property to existing annexed property. (Ord. 640, 4-
16-1979; amd. Ord. 735, 9-15-1980; 1983 Code)

Chapter 11
ANNEXATION PROCEDURES
1-11-1: APPLICATION FOR ANNEXATION; CONTENTS:
Applications for annexation shall be made to the Planning Department in accordance with Section 9-9-2 of this Code. Annexation requests shall not be
heard by the Planning and Zoning Commission unless and until an application for annexation is submitted to the Planning Department. The application
must contain the following:
A. Name, address and telephone number of the applicant.
B. A vicinity map showing property divisions and ownerships within three hundred feet (300') of the external boundaries of the parcel; excluded from the
measurement are rights of way.
C. A legal survey of the parcel, tied at least to one section corner, with the metes and bounds description written in a counterclockwise direction and
compatible with the existing City corporate description. The survey shall be submitted in triplicate, drawn to a scale of no less than one hundred feet to
the inch (100' = 1").
D. A list of the owners of the parcels to be annexed; and if individual ownership is larger than five (5) acres, a notarized statement requesting annexation.
E. A statement by the owners stating whether they agree or do not agree to participate in a local improvement district for all standard improvements to the
right-of-way adjoining the property. (Ord. 762, 11-15-1982)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 13/303
1-11-2: APPLICABILITY:
A. The proposed annexation must conform to Idaho Code1.
B. The parcel of land shall be adjoining the corporate limits and be within the proposed corporate limits of the Comprehensive Plan Map. (Ord. 762, 11-15-
1982)
1-11-3: ZONING:
All properties shall be zoned in accordance with the Comprehensive Plan Map. (Ord. 762, 11-15-1982)
1-11-4: REQUIRED STANDARDS:
A. Fire hydrants shall be installed by the applicant at the direction and at the discretion of the Fire Chief.
B. Sidewalks shall be constructed along the through street as directed by the City Council.
C. A landscape maintenance plan, approved by the Commission shall become part of the annexation requirements. Failure to maintain property in
accordance with such plan shall constitute a nuisance subjecting the property owner to criminal and civil penalties and assessment for maintenance
provided by the City.
D. Owners of parcels previously developed shall be required to make dedications or improvements to conform to the ordinances in effect at the time of
annexation, unless specifically exempted by the City Council.
E. Upon presentation of petition for annexation initiated by landowners of areas adjacent to the City's corporate limits, the petition must be accompanied
by: 1) an agreement with the Sandpoint Independent Highway District providing for inclusion of the area to be annexed within the boundaries of the
Independent Highway District; or 2) an agreement between the said Independent Highway District and the Bonner County Commissioners formally to
include the area to be annexed within the boundaries of the said Independent Highway District.
F. Where annexation affects property on only one side of a public right of way, no part of the public right of way shall be included in the annexation.
G. Where annexation includes a public right of way, property annexed must be of a depth of not less than fifty feet (50') wherever it lies adjacent to the
public right of way. (Ord. 762, 11-15-1982)
1-11-5: FEES:
An application shall not be processed until all filing fees are paid in full. Such fees will be set from time to time by the City Council. (Ord. 762, 11-15-1982)
Chapter 12
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION
1-12-1: CREATION; PURPOSE:
A. The city does hereby create a public corporation to carry out the purposes of the "act"1. This chapter shall not be construed to limit or restrict the
purposes of the act, but shall be liberally construed to effect such purposes.
B. The name of the public corporation shall be the "Economic Development Corporation of Sandpoint" (the "corporation"). (Ord. 772, 1-17-1983)
1-12-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The corporation shall have all the powers and be subject to all the limitations and provisions contained in the act. The corporation shall have all the powers
granted by the act. Such powers shall include, without limitation, all powers set forth in the charter, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk
and adopted herein as if set out in full. (Ord. 772, 1-17-1983)
1-12-3: CHARTER:
A charter (the "charter") is hereby issued by the city to the corporation. The charter grants to the corporation all powers authorized by the act. A copy of the
charter is on file in the office of the city clerk and incorporated herein by reference. The charter is hereby approved pursuant to section 50-2703(1) of the
act. The charter may be amended from time to time by the city council. The existence of the corporation commences at the time the enactment of this
chapter becomes effective. (Ord. 772, 1-17-1983)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 14/303
1-12-4: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
The board of directors of the corporation (the "board") shall be comprised of three (3) to seven (7) persons, a majority of whom shall be residents of the
city of Sandpoint or persons who own, manage, or are employed by a business within the Sandpoint city limits, appointed by the mayor and confirmed by
the city council. Each member shall be appointed to a three (3) year term. If a vacancy occurs during an unexpired term, the mayor, with the consent of the
council, shall appoint a member to serve the remainder of the unexpired term. A majority of the members of the board shall constitute a quorum, and the
approval of a majority of a quorum shall be necessary for the board to take any action. (Ord. 811, 8-19-1985; amd. Ord. 994, 11-20-1996; Ord. 1150, 6-21-
2006)
1-12-5: CONDUCT OF AFFAIRS; OFFICERS:
A. The affairs of the corporation shall be conducted and carried out by the board. The board shall elect officers from among its own members. Such
officers shall be elected at the initial meeting of the board in each calendar year, shall serve until their successors have been duly elected, and shall
include a president and a secretary and may include a vice president and an assistant secretary (provided that in the event the board shall be
comprised of only 3 members, the offices of vice president and assistant secretary may be simultaneously held by the same person; and, provided
further, that in the event the offices of the vice president and assistant secretary shall be simultaneously held by the same person, such person shall
not both execute and attest any resolution, document, certificate, deed, mortgage, deed of trust, note, bond, contract or other document or instrument).
The board may elect such other officers as it shall from time to time determine to be necessary or desirable.
B. The board shall adopt bylaws and/or rules and regulations governing the election of officers, the power and duties of such officers, the filling of
vacancies in offices, the scheduling, giving notice of and conduct of meetings and the conduct of the corporation. Such bylaws, rules and regulations
may be amended from time to time by the board, provided any such amendments shall be consistent with the provisions hereof.
C. Members of the board shall serve without compensation, but with reimbursement of expenses as may be provided in the bylaws, rules and regulations
of the board. (Ord. 772, 1-17-1983)
1-12-6: CONFLICTS OF INTEREST:
No director, officer, agent, employee or official of the corporation shall have a direct or indirect financial interest in any property to be included in or any
contract for property, service or materials to be furnished or used in connection with any industrial development facility financed through the corporation.
(Ord. 772, 1-17-1983)
1-12-7: MONIES; LENDING OR USE OF:
A. The city may not give or lend any money or property in aid of the corporation, except as expressly authorized by the act. This provision shall not
preclude the city from dealing with the corporation on an arm's length basis.
B. Any net earnings of the corporation beyond those necessary for retirement of indebtedness incurred by it shall inure to the city and not for the benefit of
any other person. Alteration of the charter of or dissolution of or audits of the corporation shall be as provided by the act and by subsequent ordinances
of the city. Upon dissolution of the corporation, title to all property owned by the corporation shall vest in the city. (Ord. 772, 1-17-1983)
Chapter 13
COLLECTIVE BARGAINING UNIT
1-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this Chapter, the following mean:
BARGAINING AGENT: The designated representative or representatives, which shall include the president or vice-president, of the employee
organization.
DESIGNATED CORPORATE REPRESENTATIVE: The individual or individuals, which shall include at least one member of the Sandpoint City Council,
appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the Council to represent the employer in negotiations.
EMPLOYEE OR PUBLIC EMPLOYEE: Any person employed by the employer on a full-time permanent or permanent part-time basis.
The following persons are excluded from the term employee or public employee for purposes of this Chapter: those persons elected by the people,
those persons appointed by the Mayor, members of boards or authorities or commissions, contract employees, attorneys for the employer, persons
employed on a temporary seasonal, full-time temporary or part-time basis, members of Local 2319 and those persons whose job descriptions, as
approved by the City Council, specifically preclude them from membership in the employees' collective bargaining organization by virtue of their
position with the City of Sandpoint.
EMPLOYEE ORGANIZATION OR ORGANIZATION: A labor organization, union, association, fraternal order or group of employees, however organized or
constituted, which represents or seeks to represent a majority of the public employees concerning employees' wages, benefits and working conditions.
EMPLOYER OR PUBLIC EMPLOYER: The City of Sandpoint, an Idaho municipal corporation. (Ord. 878, 12-19-1988)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 15/303
1-13-2: RECOGNITION PROCEDURES:
A. The employee organization may file a petition with the City Council for recognition as the representative of public employees for the purpose of
employment negotiations. The petition shall contain the following:
1. The name, affiliation, if any, and address of the petitioning employee organization and each of its designated representatives to the City;
2. A list of its elected officers, if any, and their addresses and telephone numbers;
3. Authorization cards, signed by at least thirty percent (30%) of the employees, which card shall include a request from the employee signing the
authorization card that the employee organization be recognized as the representative of that employee.
B. The City Council shall investigate the petition to determine its sufficiency and whether a request concerning representation by an employee organization
has been made.
C. After a petition is filed pursuant to the provisions of subsection A of this Section, and the City Council, following investigation of the petition, finds that a
request concerning representation by an employee organization has been made, the City Council shall:
1. Define the proposed bargaining unit and determine which public employees shall be qualified and entitled to vote in any election; and,
2. Order an election by secret ballot to be conducted within thirty (30) days of receipt of the petition.
D. Cause petitions for recognition and/or petitions to intervene to be posted on the official bulletin board of the City within two (2) days of receipt thereof by
the City Council. (Ord. 878, 12-19-1988)
1-13-3: ELECTION COMMITTEE:
When an election has been ordered, an Election Committee of one person selected by the Council, one person selected by the employees, and a third
person selected by the other two (2) persons shall conduct such election. The Election Committee shall:
A. Fix the date, time and polling place for the election;
B. Direct the manner in which notice of the election shall be given;
C. Supervise and regulate the election and resolve any disputes arising in the course of the election;
D. Certify the results of the election to the Mayor and City Council; and,
E. Assure that the provisions of Section 1-13-4 of this Chapter governing such elections are followed. (Ord. 878, 12-19-1988)
1-13-4: REPRESENTATION ELECTIONS:
A. An election shall be held within thirty (30) days following receipt by the City Council of a petition for recognition.
B. The election ballot shall contain the name of the petitioning employee organization.
C. Notices of the election shall be posted as soon as is practicable after the date, time and place of the election are fixed by the Election Committee;
however, all notices shall be posted at least ten (10) working days prior to the date of the election.
D. The employer and the employee organization may each designate one observer for each polling place. The observer shall wear a visible name tag
which includes their title. The function of an observer shall be to act as an observer at each polling place and to assist in the identification of voters.
E. The organization selected by a simple majority of the public employees, as certified by the Election Committee, shall be certified by the Mayor and City
Council as the sole and exclusive bargaining agent for the bargaining unit which was the subject of the election. (Ord. 878, 12-19-1988)
1-13-5: NEGOTIATIONS:
A. It shall be the obligation of the City, through its designated corporate representatives to bargain in good faith with the bargaining agent within thirty (30)
days after receipt of written notice requesting a meeting for collective bargaining purposes. The bargaining agent shall bargain in good faith with the
City.
To bargain in good faith is the performance of the mutual obligation of the City's designated corporate representatives and the bargaining agent to meet
solely with one another at reasonable times and to negotiate in good faith with respect to wages, hours and other terms and conditions of employment.
This obligation shall include the duty to cause any agreement resulting from negotiations between the bargaining agent and the designated corporate
representatives to be reduced to a written contract.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 16/303
B. Whenever wages, rates of pay or any other matter requiring appropriation of money by the City are included as a matter of collective bargaining
conducted under the provisions of this Chapter, it is the obligation of the bargaining agent to serve written notice of request for collective bargaining on
the employer at least ninety (90) days before the last day on which money can be appropriated by the City (pursuant to Idaho Code 50-1007) to cover
the contract period which is the subject of the collective bargaining procedure.
C. In the event that the bargaining agent and the designated corporate representatives are unable, within sixty (60) days from and including the date of
their first meeting, to reach an agreement on a contract, any and all unresolved issues shall be submitted to a fact finding commission whose decision
shall be binding. The decision, as it relates to funding, shall be binding to the extent that funds are available to the city for complying with any monetary
requirements of the decision. (Ord. 878, 12-19-1988)
D. Within five (5) working days from the expiration of the sixty (60) day period referred to in subsection C of this section, the bargaining agent and the
employer shall each select and name one member of the fact finding commission respectively and shall immediately thereafter notify each other, in
writing, of the names and addresses of the person so selected.
The two (2) members so selected and named shall, within five (5) working days from and after the expiration of the five (5) working day period above
mentioned, agree upon and appoint and name a third member. If, on the expiration of the five (5) working day period, the two (2) members are unable
to agree upon the appointment of a third member, the state labor commission shall appoint such third member upon written request from either the
bargaining agent or the corporate authorities. The third member of the fact finding commission, whether appointed as a result of agreement between
the two (2) members selected by the bargaining agent and the employer, or appointed by the state labor commission, shall act as chairman of the fact
finding commission. No member of the fact finding commission shall be an elected official, an official of the employee organization, or on the city
payroll. Any expenses incurred by the third member of the fact finding commission shall be equally shared by the bargaining agent and the employer,
and each of those parties shall be solely responsible for the payment of the expenses of its member of the commission.
E. Fact finding shall be conducted as follows:
1. The fact finding commission shall appoint a time and place for hearing and cause notification to the bargaining agent and the employer to be served
personally or by registered mail not less than five (5) working days before the meeting. Appearances at the hearing waive such notice requirement.
The fact finding commission may adjourn the hearing from time to time, as necessary, and, on request of a party for good cause or upon their own
motion, may postpone the hearing. The fact finding commission shall hear and determine the controversy upon the evidence produced,
notwithstanding the failure of a party duly notified to appear. (Ord. 1274, 7-18-2012)
2. The bargaining agent and the employer shall be entitled to be heard, to present evidence material to the controversy and to cross examine
witnesses appearing at the hearing.
3. The hearing shall be conducted by all of the members of the fact finding commission, but a majority may determine any question and render a
decision.
F. The binding decision of the fact finding commission shall be rendered within thirty (30) days after the end of the hearing, and shall be in writing and
signed by the members of the commission. The decision, as it relates to funding, shall be binding to the extent that funds are available to the city for
complying with any monetary requirements of the decision. The fact finding commission shall deliver a copy of the decision to the bargaining agent and
corporate authorities.
If the fact finding commission is unable to render a timely decision, either party may petition the district court for relief.
G. The following shall relate to unfair labor practices:
1. It shall be an unfair labor practice for the employer, the employees, or the bargaining representative to:
a. Interfere with or coerce the employees in the exercise of their legal rights.
b. Discriminate against any employee who has filed a grievance or unfair labor practice charge.
c. Refuse to engage in collective bargaining.
2. Whenever a charge has been made concerning any unfair labor practice, the parties agree to submit the dispute to the department of labor and
industrial services. Those charges must be filed within fifteen (15) days of their occurrence.
3. A time and date for the hearing shall be scheduled no more than thirty (30) days after the charges have been filed.
4. During the hearing, both parties shall have the opportunity to present evidence and call and examine witnesses. The Department of Labor and
Industrial Services shall have the power to issue subpoenas requiring the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of any evidence
that relates to any matter under investigation or in question.
5. The Department of Labor and Industrial Services shall issue its decision within sixty (60) days after the conclusion of the hearing. Those findings
shall be final and binding on all parties. The findings, as they relate to funding, shall be binding to the extent that funds are available to the City for
complying with any monetary requirements of the decision. (Ord. 878, 12-19-1988)
1-13-6: PUBLIC EMPLOYEES' RIGHTS:
Public employees shall have the right to form, join and participate in, or to refrain from forming, joining or participating in any employee organization, the
right to be represented in negotiations over working conditions with the employer, and the right to exercise these rights without discrimination. (Ord. 878,
12-19-1988)
1-13-7: PUBLIC EMPLOYERS' RIGHTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 17/303
The public employer shall have the right to manage the affairs of the City and to direct its working forces, the right to set standards of service, the right to
hire and determine the procedures and standards of selection for employment and promotion, the right to discipline or discharge for proper cause, the right
to lay off for lack of work or funds, the right to make rules and regulations governing conduct, the right to determine the methods, processes and manner of
performing work and the right to establish job descriptions and work classifications. (Ord. 878, 12-19-1988)
1-13-8: NO STRIKE; NO LOCK OUT:
At no time may any employee or employee organization engage in any strike, slowdown or work stoppage, nor may the City lock out any of its employees.
(Ord. 878, 12-19-1988)
Chapter 14
CITY FUNDS
1-14-1: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS:
A. The City Finance Director/Treasurer is hereby authorized to place all funds classified as deposits in a banking institution that is a member of the
F.D.I.C., Sandpoint branch.
B. The City Council shall periodically designate the actual banking institution by resolution. (Ord. 1003, 6-18-1997)
1-14-2: INVESTMENT OF FUNDS:
The Finance Director/Treasurer shall be empowered to place all other funds not classified as deposits in investment accounts pursuant to resolutions
passed by the City Council. (Ord. 1003, 6-18-1997)
Chapter 15
PERFORMANCE MEASUREMENT STANDARDS
1-15-1: KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS TO BE MAINTAINED:
A. All City departments shall maintain key performance indicators regarding monthly department performance, as directed by the City Administrator.
B. All City contracted entities shall maintain key performance indicators regarding monthly contracted performance, as directed by the City Administrator.
(Ord. 1357, 9-5-2018)
1-15-2: ALIGNMENT OF GOALS AND KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS:
By August of each calendar year, the City Administrator shall present the Operational Plan and proposed budget for Council review, which will demonstrate
for Council the alignment of City-wide operational goals and departmental goals and key performance indicators with Council priorities as established in
the City's 5-year Strategic Plan. (Ord. 1357, 9-5-2018)
1-15-3: CITY ADMINISTRATOR DUTIES:
A. The City Administrator shall assure long-range operational plans for all major City functions be in-place and kept up-to-date.
B. The City Administrator will routinely measure, analyze, and report to Council City-wide progress on operational key performance indicators and adopt
subsequent plans in an effort to continuously improve outcomes.
C. The City Administrator shall implement a process to ensure that the programs supported with Federal and/or State funds achieve measurable results
that support City goals, and shall ensure that measurement, monitoring, and reporting of these results meet funding source requirements.
D. The City Administrator shall annually assess and make recommendation for Council approval the appropriation of sufficient resources and subsequent
strategies necessary to meet the data information needs of Council, City Administration, City commissions, and Sandpoint citizens. (Ord. 1357, 9-5-
2018)
1-15-4: UTILIZATION OF KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATOR INFORMATION:
The City Council, City Administrator, and all City departments and divisions shall utilize information provided through the analysis of key performance
indicators when making policy, program, or any other decisions that will impact the City's service delivery capabilities. (Ord. 1357, 9-5-2018)
