Title 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 1
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
2-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter:
APPOINTIVE MEMBERS: All voting members of the Commission.
COMMISSION: The Planning and Zoning Commission.
EX OFFICIO MEMBERS: Nonvoting ex-officio advisors appointed by the Planning and Zoning Commission. (Ord. 633, 2-20-1979)
2-1-2: COMMISSION CREATED; QUALIFICATIONS:
There is hereby created a commission to be known as the Planning and Zoning Commission of the City, which Commission shall consist of seven (7)
members to be appointed by the Mayor subject to confirmation of the Council.
Members of the Commission shall be selected without respect to political affiliation and shall serve without compensation. Members shall be residents of
the City; with the exception of one member who may be a nonresident of the City. Each and every member of the Commission shall meet the statutory
resident qualifications as set forth in Idaho Code 67-6504(a). (Ord. 633, 2-20-1979)
2-1-3: TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES:
A. Terms: The term of office for appointive members of the Commission shall be for three (3) years; provided, however, that the term of office of the three
(3) members of the initial Commission appointed hereunder shall be for a term of four (4) years. The term of office of the initial Commission members
appointed hereunder shall be determined by lot and all members appointed thereafter shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years.
B. Vacancies: Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of terms of office shall be filled in the same manneras original appointments;
provided, that a member appointed to fill a thus created vacancy shall be appointed to complete the term of office of the member whose departure from
the Commission created said vacancy.
C. Removal: Members of the Commission may be removed by a majority vote of the City Council. (Ord. 633, 2-20-1979)
2-1-4: RULES AND ORGANIZATION:
A. The Commission shall elect its own chairman and create and fill such other offices as it may determine required for the proper conduct of the affairs and
business of the Commission. (Ord. 633, 2-20-1979)
B. The Commission may appoint nonvoting ex officio advisors as may be deemed necessary, whose terms of office shall be one year. (Ord. 711, 3-17-
1980)
C. A majority of the appointive members of the Commission shall be necessary to constitute a quorum at any meeting.
D. Written organization papers and/or bylaws consistent with this Chapter and the laws of the State of Idaho for the transaction of business of the
Commission shall be adopted and confirmed by the City Council.
E. A record of meetings, hearings, resolutions, studies, findings, permits and actions taken shall be maintained and shall be open to the public.
F. At least one regular meeting shall be held each month for not less than nine (9) months in each calendar year. (Ord. 633, 2-20-1979)
2-1-5: DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION:
The Commission created hereunder shall perform such functions and duties as required by and in furtherance of those planning and zoning matters set
forth in the Local Planning Act of 1975 and contained in Idaho Code sections 67-6501 through 67-6529. The Commission shall further perform such
functions and fulfill such duties as assigned to the Commission by the City Council, and may at any time make recommendations to the City Council
concerning the plan, planning processes, implementation of the plan and zoning processes.
With the consent of the owner, the Commission and its members, officers and employees in the performance of their function may enter upon any land and
make examination and survey and place and maintain necessary monuments and marks thereon. (Ord. 633, 2-20-1979)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 19/303
2-1-6: MEETINGS:
The City's regular Planning and Zoning Commission meeting shall be set by the City Council by resolution. Should the meeting date fall on a holiday, the
Commission meeting shall be held on the next regular business day following. (Ord. 841, 6-15-1987)
Chapter 2
DEVELOPMENT IMPACT FEE ADVISORY COMMITTEE
2-2-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
This chapter shall establish a development impact fee advisory committee pursuant to Idaho Code 67-8205. (Ord. 987, 6-19-1996)
2-2-2: APPOINTMENT:
The development impact fee advisory committee shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council pursuant to Idaho Code. (Ord. 987, 6-
19-1996)
2-2-3: MEMBERSHIP:
A. The development impact fee advisory committee shall be composed of not fewer than five (5) members.
B. At least two (2) members of the development impact fee advisory committee shall be active in the business of development, building or real estate.
Members under this category who miss two (2) consecutive meetings shall be automatically removed from the committee and replaced pursuant to the
appointment process outlined in this chapter.
C. At least two (2) members shall be persons who are not officials of or employees of the city of Sandpoint. (Ord. 1224, 12-16-2009, eff. 1-1-2010)
2-2-4: DUTIES AND FUNCTIONS:
A. The development impact fee advisory committee shall serve in an advisory capacity only.
B. The function of the development impact fee advisory committee shall be to:
1. Assist the local government in adopting land use assumptions.
2. Review the capital improvements plan, and proposed amendments, and file written comments.
3. Monitor and evaluate implementation of the capital improvements plan.
4. File periodic reports at least annually with respect to the capital improvements plan and report to the mayor and city council any perceived inequities
in implementing the plan or imposing the development impact fees.
5. Advise the mayor and city council of the need to update or revise land use assumptions, capital improvements plan, and development impact fees.
(Ord. 987, 6-19-1996)
2-2-5: AVAILABILITY OF RECORDS:
The city of Sandpoint shall make available to the advisory committee upon request all financial and accounting information, professional reports in relation
to other development and implementation of land use assumptions, the capital improvements plan, and periodic updates of the capital improvements plan.
Request for such data and information shall be made through the mayor, who shall assure response from the appropriate employees, departments and
professional staff. (Ord. 987, 6-19-1996)
Chapter 3
HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION
2-3-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to promote the educational, cultural, economic, and general welfare of the public of the city of Sandpoint through
identification, evaluation, designation, and protection of those buildings, sites, districts, areas, structures, and objects that reflect significant elements of the
city's, the state's, and the nation's historic, architectural, archaeological, and cultural heritage. (Ord. 1081, 2-19-2003)
2-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 20/303
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the following meanings:
CITY: The city of Sandpoint.
COMMISSION: The historic preservation commission of the city of Sandpoint created by this chapter with the duties and responsibilities set forth herein.
DESIGNATED HISTORIC PROPERTY: In order for any historic property to be designated in the ordinance, it must, in addition, meet the criteria
established for inclusion of the property in the national register of historic places.
HISTORIC PRESERVATION: The identification, evaluation, recordation, documentation, curation, acquisition, management, protection, restoration,
rehabilitation, stabilization, maintenance, interpretation, conservation, and education of buildings, structures, objects, districts, areas, and sites significant
in the history, architecture, archaeology, or culture of this state, its communities, or the nation.
HISTORIC PROPERTY: Any building, structure, district, area, or site that is significant in the history, architecture, archaeology, or culture of this
community, the state, or the nation. (Ord. 1081, 2-19-2003)
2-3-3: ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP:
A. There is hereby created a historic preservation commission which shall consist of at least five (5) but not more than nine (9) members who shall receive
no salary. They shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council, and members may, in like manner, be removed without cause. One
member of the city council shall act as a nonvoting liaison. One member may be a city of Sandpoint planning and zoning commissioner; one member
may be from a downtown business association; and at least three (3) members must be knowledgeable in Sandpoint history and architecture. All
members of the commission shall have a demonstrated interest, competence, or knowledge in history or historic preservation. The council shall
endeavor to appoint at least two (2) members with professional training or experience in the disciplines of architecture, history, architectural history,
urban planning, archaeology, engineering, conservation, landscape architecture, law, or other historic preservation related disciplines. A majority of the
members of this commission shall be city residents.
B. Initial appointments to the commission shall be made as follows: One 1-year term; two (2) 2-year terms; and two (2) 3-year terms. All subsequent
appointments shall be made for three (3) year terms. Commission members may be reappointed to serve additional terms. In the event there are
greater than five (5) members, each new appointee's term shall be staggered to allow no more than three (3) members' terms expiring in the same
year.
C. The Mayor shall determine which of the first appointed members' term of office shall expire after adoption of this chapter, and which shall expire at the
first City Council meeting one year and two (2) years after adoption of this chapter.
D. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments, and the appointee shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term. (Ord.
1282, 6-5-2013)
2-3-4: ORGANIZATION, OFFICERS, RULES, AND MEETINGS:
A. The commission shall have the authority, subject to Sandpoint City Council approval, to make reasonable rules necessary for the execution of its duties,
as set forth in this chapter. Rules of procedure and bylaws, if any, adopted by the commission, shall be available for public inspection.
B. The commission shall elect officers from among the commission members. The Chairperson shall preside at meetings of the commission. The Vice
Chairperson shall, lacking the Chairperson, perform the duties of the Chairperson.
C. The Historic Preservation Commission shall meet at a regular place and time determined by the commission. All meetings of the commission shall
follow the requirements of Idaho's Open Meeting Laws to allow and promote public participation in the decisions of the commission. The commission
shall keep minutes and other appropriate written records of its resolutions, proceedings, and actions.
D. The commission will report at least annually to the Mayor and the City Council. The Mayor or the Mayor's designee may appoint from the staff of the
City of Sandpoint an ex officio member and Secretary of the commission. Said ex officio member shall have no voting privileges.
E. The commission may recommend to the City Council, within the limits of its funding, the employment of or the contracting with other parties for the
services of technical experts or other persons it deems necessary to carry on the functions of the commission. (Ord. 1081, 2-19-2003)
2-3-5: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The commission shall be advisory to the City Council, and to the extent permitted by law, shall be authorized to:
A. Facilitate the identification, preservation, protection, and enhancement of areas of special interest, historic value, and scenic beauty through the
following ways:
1. Encourage preservation of historically and architecturally significant properties.
2. Encourage the use of historically and architecturally significant properties for practical, useful purposes.
3. Encourage compatible development in areas of historic properties.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 21/303
4. Establish and facilitate local input in the designation of significant structures at the State and national levels, and establish a local Historic Resources
Program.
5. Encourage preservation of the community's interest in scenic and waterfront areas.
6. Assist in obtaining grants and donations in support of historic preservation. (Ord. 1296, 2-5-2014)
B. Develop a Historical Resources Program for the City of Sandpoint area which may include the following:
1. Develop and maintain a priority listing of historic and architecturally significant properties in the City that is based on the value of the structures and
their potential for preservation.
2. Recommend to the Sandpoint City Council properties and sites in the City of Sandpoint for nomination to the National Register.
3. Develop and implement, with the approval of the City Council, a visual form of recognition for significant properties to be designed, awarded, and
distributed. (Ord. 1081, 2-19-2003)
4. Develop and recommend a means by which merchants and property owners, as well as property owners elsewhere in the City, are encouraged to
preserve and restore significant properties in the Central Business District and to maintain architectural compatibility and character between new
structures or remodeling projects and existing structures. (Ord. 1348, 10-4-2017)
5. Promote and conduct an educational and interpretive program on historic properties within its jurisdiction.
C. Recommend appropriate zoning in areas of significant historic properties to ensure future compatible development resolution.
D. Cooperate with the Federal, State, and local governments in the pursuance of the objectives of historic preservation.
E. Recommend ordinances and otherwise provide information for the purposes of historic preservation to the County or City Governing Body.
F. Perform such other duties and responsibilities as the Mayor and City Council may from time to time assign, including, when approved by the Mayor and
City Council, such duties and responsibilities as may be permitted by law. (Ord. 1081, 2-19-2003)
2-3-6: SPECIAL RESTRICTIONS:
The adoption of this chapter shall not in any manner affect the validity of any action heretofore taken by the Sandpoint City Council or the validity of any
such action to be taken upon matters pending before the Sandpoint City Council on the effective date hereof. (Ord. 1081, 2-19-2003)
Chapter 4
PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION
2-4-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the parks and recreation commission (hereinafter commission) to act in an advisory capacity to the directors of the parks and recreation
departments, the mayor, and city council to aid in the process of effective, responsible, and efficient government by:
A. Marshaling and channeling the resources available in the community to complement the judgment of city council and staff;
B. Providing a forum for dialog and public input;
C. Providing mechanisms appropriate to ascertain facts and discern views; and
D. Broadening citizen participation in self-government. (Ord. 1094, 10-15-2003)
2-4-2: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby established and created a commission to be known as the Sandpoint parks and recreation commission. (Ord. 1094, 10-15-2003)
2-4-3: DUTIES:
The commission shall be advisory to the parks and recreation directors, the mayor, and city council and, to the extent permitted by law, shall be authorized
to assist the parks director and the recreation director as follows:
A. To undertake a complete, comprehensive study and make recommendations to the city staff as to the needs for community recreation programs and
projects for persons of all ages.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 22/303
B. To determine and advise the city staff of the desires of the public concerning recreation requirements, the need for additional parks and park facilities,
as well as review and update the parks master plan.
C. To advise and recommend to the city staff the types of facilities required to accomplish the goals of a sound and comprehensive recreation program.
D. To inform the public of established recreational facilities/programs and to educate the public on the methods of improving recreational
facilities/programs.
E. To solicit support and cooperation among the citizens and various organizations of the community in the development, construction, and financing of
recreation programs/facilities.
F. To appoint members of subcommittees to provide community information to the commission concerning particular park facilities or recreational
programs.
G. To encourage multiuse and nonexclusive park facilities.
H. To review and make recommendations to the city staff on park and recreational fees, and/or rental fees.
I. To advise, through the appropriate director, the mayor, and city council in regard to the foregoing provisions. (Ord. 1094, 10-15-2003)
2-4-4: ORGANIZATION OF COMMISSION:
A. Membership: There shall be no fewer than five (5) and no more than nine (9) voting members of the commission, to be appointed by the mayor and
confirmed by the city council. If possible, one member thereof shall be a member of the school board (or an administrative staff person of the Lake
Pend Oreille School District 84) and a high school student between the ages of fourteen (14) and eighteen (18) years old. One member of the city
council shall act as a liaison. The other members shall be chosen as citizens at large from the residents of the city, providing that one member may
reside outside the city limits.
B. Staff Appointment: The parks director and the recreation director shall be ex officio members of the commission. The mayor or mayor's designee may
appoint from the staff of the city of Sandpoint a secretary of the commission. Ex officio members shall have no voting privileges.
C. Vacancies On Commission: The mayor, to be confirmed by the city council, shall fill any vacancies occurring in the membership of the commission.
D. Quorum: A majority of the appointed members of the commission shall be necessary to constitute a quorum and conduct any business at any
commission meeting.
E. Removal Of Members: Any member of the commission may be removed with or without cause by a majority vote of the entire city council.
F. Nonpolitical; No Compensation: The members of the commission shall be selected without regard to political affiliations and shall serve without
compensation.
G. Organization: At the first meeting of each fiscal year or as soon thereafter as practicable, the members of the commission shall meet and organize to
elect a chairperson, vice chairperson, and fill such other offices as determined necessary. The chairperson shall preside at meetings of the
commission. The vice chairperson shall, when the chairperson is absent, perform the duties of the chairperson.
H. Commission Terms: Each member of the commission shall serve a term of three (3) years or until his or her successor is appointed and qualified,
except for the high school student, whose term shall be one year. Vacancies arising in any member's position shall be filled for the remaining term of
the member originally appointed.
1. Initial appointments to the commission shall be made as follows: three (3) 1-year terms; three (3) 2-year terms; and three (3) 3-year terms. All
subsequent appointments shall be made for three (3) year terms (evenly staggered if there are fewer members). Commission members may be
reappointed to serve additional terms.
2. The mayor shall determine the term of office for first appointed members, consistent with subsection H1 of this section.
3. The ex officio members of the parks and recreation commission shall hold office corresponding with their respective tenures in regular city
administrative positions, and may be removed and replaced by the mayor. (Ord. 1094, 10-15-2003)
2-4-5: MEETINGS:
The commission shall meet at a regular place and time as determined by the commission. All meetings of the commission shall follow the requirements of
Idaho's open meeting laws to allow and promote public participation in the decisions of the commission. The commission shall keep minutes and other
appropriate written records of its resolutions, proceedings, and actions. (Ord. 1094, 10-15-2003)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 23/303
2-4-6: RULES:
The commission shall have the authority, subject to Sandpoint city council approval, to make reasonable rules necessary for the execution of its duties as
set forth in this chapter. Rules of procedure and bylaws, if any, adopted by the commission shall be available for public inspection. The commission shall
make a written record of the meetings, its resolutions, findings, determinations, and of its recommendations, which said written record shall be kept as a
permanent public record. The commissionwill give monthly updates to the mayor and the city council, when appropriate. (Ord. 1094, 10-15-2003)
Chapter 5
ARTS COMMISSION
2-5-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND TITLE:
There is hereby established and created a commission to be known as the Sandpoint arts commission (hereinafter "commission"). (Ord. 1106, 2-18-2004)
2-5-2: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the commission to act in an advisory capacity to the mayor and city council to create and maintain an atmosphere conducive to the
fullest expression of all forms of the arts in order to enrich the lives of all Sandpoint citizens and visitors through public art. (Ord. 1106, 2-18-2004)
2-5-3: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The commission shall advise and assist the mayor and city council with respect to developing, coordinating, and promoting the performing and visual arts
for the enjoyment, education, cultural enrichment and benefit of the citizens of Sandpoint. In furtherance of these duties, the commission shall attempt to
accomplish, subject to council approval, the following objectives:
A. Encourage the preservation and growth of the city's art resources and advance Sandpoint as an arts and cultural destination.
B. Work with arts organizations, public agencies and community representatives, to plan and promote arts activities, provide opportunities for residents to
participate in artistic activities.
C. Assist in obtaining grants and donations in support of the arts, and encourage the donation of public art within the city.
D. Foster opportunities for artists to advance their art forms and recognize the achievements and excellence of outstanding artists and increase public
access to their works.
E. Encourage a public collection of artworks with strong inherent aesthetic qualities and a wide range of artistic styles and disciplines. (Ord. 1106, 2-18-
2004)
2-5-4: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS OF OFFICE, VACANCIES:
The commission shall consist of no fewer than seven (7) and no more than nine (9) voting members of the commission, to be appointed by the mayor and
confirmed by the city council. One member of the city council shall act as a liaison. The members shall be chosen as citizens at large from the residents of
the city, providing that three (3) members may reside outside the city limits. The members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 1270, 6-20-2012)
A. Commission Terms/Vacancies: Each member of the commission shall serve a term of three (3) years or until his or her successor is appointed and
qualified. Vacancies arising in any member's position shall be filled for the remaining term of the member originally appointed. Initial appointments to
the commission shall be made as follows: three (3) 1-year terms; three (3) 2-year terms; and three (3) 3-year terms. All subsequent appointments shall
be made for three (3) year terms (evenly staggered if there are fewer members). Commission members may be reappointed to serve additional terms.
The mayor shall determine the term of office for first appointed members, consistent with this section. The ex officio member of the commission shall
hold office corresponding with their respective tenures in regular city administrative positions, and may be removed and replaced by the mayor. The
mayor shall fill any vacancies occurring in the membership of the commission, with the appointment to be confirmed by the city council.
B. Organization And Quorum: At the first meeting of each fiscal year or as soon thereafter as practicable, the members of the commission shall meet and
organize to elect a chairperson, vice chairperson, and fill such other offices as determined necessary. The chairperson shall preside at meetings of the
commission. The vice chairperson shall, when the chairperson is absent, perform the duties of the chairperson. A majority of the appointed members of
the commission shall be necessary to constitute a quorum and conduct any business at any commission meeting.
C. Removal Of Members: Any member of the commission may be removed with or without cause by the mayor with the consent of the city council.
D. Meetings: The commission shall meet at a regular place and time as determined by the commission. All meetings of the commission shall follow the
requirements of Idaho's open meeting laws to allow and promote public participation in the decisions of the commission. The commission shall keep
minutes and other appropriate written records of its resolutions, proceedings, and actions.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 24/303
E. Rules: The commission shall have the authority, subject to Sandpoint city council approval, to make reasonable rules necessary for the execution of its
duties as set forth in this chapter. Rules of procedure and bylaws, if any, adopted by the commission shall be available for public inspection. The
commission shall make a written record of the meetings, its resolutions, findings, determinations, and of its recommendations, which said written record
shall be kept as a permanent public record. The commission will give monthly updates to the mayor and the city council, when appropriate. (Ord. 1106,
2-18-2004)
Chapter 6
PEDESTRIAN AND BICYCLE ADVISORY COMMITTEE
2-6-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND TITLE:
There is hereby established and created a committee to be known as the Sandpoint pedestrian and bicycle advisory committee (hereinafter "committee").
(Ord. 1250, 12-15-2010, eff. after 1-1-2011)
2-6-2: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the committee to advise the mayor, city council, and planning and zoning commission on pedestrian and bicycle issues throughout and
in the vicinity of the city of Sandpoint; to make recommendations regarding pedestrian and bicycle transportation (and ways to encourage such
transportation); to provide suggestions and information on location of and methods to establish walkways and bikeways; to provide suggestions that will
increase the safety of all transportation modalities; and to assist with community education regarding pedestrian and bicycle issues. (Ord. 1250, 12-15-
2010, eff. after 1-1-2011)
2-6-3: ORGANIZATION:
A. Members: The committee shall consist of no fewer than five (5) and no more than nine (9) voting members of the committee, to be appointed by the
mayor and confirmed by the city council. The committee shall strive to include at least one member who is disabled or who cannot otherwise operate a
motorized vehicle for transportation. Members must be supporters of a strong walking and bicycling transportation system within and outside the city.
Ex officio members may include a council member and the chairpersons of any similar committees established by Bonner County or neighboring
municipalities.
B. Vacancies: The mayor shall fill any vacancies with new members to be confirmed by the city council.
C. Quorum: A majority of the appointed members of the committee shall constitute a quorum and conduct any business at any committee meeting.
D. Removal Of Members: Any member of the committee may be removed with or without cause by the mayor with the consent of the city council.
E. Nonpolitical/No Compensation: The members of the committee shall be selected without regard to political affiliations and shall serve without
compensation.
F. Organization: At the first meeting of each fiscal year or as soon thereafter as practicable, the members of the committee shall meet and organize to elect
a chairperson, vice chairperson, and fill such other offices as determined necessary. The chairperson shall preside at meetings of the committee. The
vice chairperson shall, when the chairperson is absent, perform the duties of the chairperson. The committee shall also elect a secretary from within its
membership, who shall be responsible for meeting minutes.
G. Committee Terms: Each member of the committee shall serve a term of three (3) years or until his or her successor is appointed and confirmed.
Vacancies arising in any member's position shall be filled for the remaining term of the member originally appointed.
1. Initial appointments to the committee shall be made as follows: one or two (2) one-year terms; two (2) 2-year terms; and two (2) or three (3) 3-year
terms. All additional appointments shall be made at the discretion of the mayor (evenly staggered if there are fewer members). Committee members
may be reappointed to serve additional terms.
2. The ex officio members of the committee shall hold office corresponding with their respective tenures in regular committee or city administrative
positions and may be removed and replaced by the mayor. (Ord. 1250, 12-15-2010, eff. after 1-1-2011)
2-6-4: DUTIES:
The committee shall:
A. Hold meetings at least four (4) times per year.
B. Help update the master plan for bike trails within and in the vicinity of the city.
C. Discuss and provide advice in regard to bicycle and pedestrian infrastructure.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 25/303
D. Study pedestrian walkway, multiuse path, and bike lane locations and conditions and advise regarding necessary improvements.
E. Study effectiveness of bike and pedestrian friendly treatments used in other communities and suggest how they may be applied in Sandpoint.
F. Advise on Americans with disabilities act requirements for public access and components of the transportation system and its extensions or additions.
G. Advise on programs to improve public awareness of and participation in nonmotorized transportation.
H. Advise in establishing city pedestrian and bicycle policies.
I. Establish, promote or support at least one event each year within the city which promotes bicycle use, pedestrian activity, sidewalks, pathways, or safety
for nonmotorized transportation.
J. When committee projects are applicable, work in conjunction with other city committees, including the planning and zoning commission and parks and
recreation commission. (Ord. 1250, 12-15-2010, eff. after 1-1-2011)
Chapter 7
SUSTAINABILITY COMMITTEE
2-7-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND TITLE:
There is hereby established and created a committee to be known as the Sandpoint sustainability committee (hereinafter "committee"). (Ord. 1283, 6-19-
2013)
2-7-2: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the committee to act in an advisory capacity to the mayor and city council to aid in the process of effective, responsible, and efficient
government, with the goal of enhancing connectivity, promoting good stewardship, ensuring resilience and fostering socioeconomic health. The goal of the
committee is to make recommendations that allow the city to meet the needs of the present, without compromising the ability to meet the needs of future
generations. (Ord. 1283, 6-19-2013)
2-7-3: ORGANIZATION:
A. Appointment: The committee shall consist of no fewer than five (5) and no more than nine (9) voting members, to be appointed by the mayor and
confirmed by the city council. A majority of the members shall live within Sandpoint city limits.
B. Members: The committee shall include the following:
1. A city council liaison, appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the city council person being appointed. The city council liaison may be removed
and replaced by the mayor. The city council liaison is a nonvoting member of the committee.
2. Members of the public, the majority of whom shall have experience and/or expertise related to sustainability.
C. Vacancies: The mayor shall fill any vacancies, with new members to be confirmed by the city council.
D. Quorum: A majority of the members of the committee shall constitute a quorum and conduct any business at any committee meeting.
E. Removal Of Members: Any member of the committee may be removed, with or without cause, by the mayor, with the consent of the city council.
F. Nonpolitical/No Compensation: The members of the committee shall be selected without regard to political affiliations and shall serve without
compensation.
G. Organization: At the first meeting of each fiscal year or as soon thereafter as practicable, the members of the committee shall meet and organize to
elect a chairperson, vice chairperson, and fill such other offices as determined necessary. The chairperson shall preside at meetings of the committee.
The vice chairperson shall, when the chairperson is absent, perform the duties of the chairperson. The committee shall also elect a secretary from
within its membership, who shall be responsible for meeting minutes.
H. Committee Terms: Each member of the committee shall serve a term of three (3) years or until his or her successor is appointed and confirmed.
Vacancies arising in any member's position shall be filled for the remaining term of the member originally appointed. Initial appointments to the
committee shall be made as follows: one or two (2) 1-year terms; one or two (2) 2-year terms; and one or two (2) 3-year terms. All additional
appointments shall be made at the discretion of the mayor (evenly staggered if there are fewer members). Committee members may be reappointed to
serve additional terms. (Ord. 1283, 6-19-2013)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 26/303
2-7-4: DUTIES:
The committee shall:
A. Hold meetings at least four (4) times per year;
B. Consider long term impact of city policies and activities on local natural resources, human resources, and economic viability;
C. Provide a forum for dialog and public input;
D. Provide mechanisms appropriate to ascertain facts and discern views; and
E. Broaden citizen participation in self-government. (Ord. 1283, 6-19-2013)
Chapter 8
PARKING COMMITTEE
2-8-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND TITLE:
There is hereby established and created a committee to be known as the Sandpoint parking committee (hereinafter "committee"). (Ord. 1327, 7-6-2016)
2-8-2: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the committee to act in an advisory capacity to the mayor and city council in order to aid in the process of effective, responsible, and
efficient government, with the goal of improving parking policies and enforcement. (Ord. 1327, 7-6-2016)
2-8-3: ORGANIZATION:
A. Number Of Committee Members: The committee shall consist of no fewer than five (5) and no more than seven (7) voting members of the committee, to
be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. A majority of the members shall live within the Sandpoint city limits.
B. Members: The committee shall include the following:
1. An ex officio city council liaison shall be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the appointed city councilperson, and may be removed and
replaced by the mayor. The city council liaison is a nonvoting member of the committee.
2. The committee shall be facilitated by a member of city staff, appointed by the mayor.
3. The mayor shall endeavor to appoint the following members from the public:
a. One downtown property owner;
b. One downtown business owner;
c. One downtown resident;
d. One downtown worker; and
e. Other interested citizens, as needed.
C. Vacancies: The mayor shall fill any vacancies with new members, to be confirmed by the city council.
D. Quorum: A majority of the members of the committee shall constitute a quorum and conduct any business at any committee meeting.
E. Removal Of Members: Any member of the committee may be removed with or without cause by the mayor, with the consent of the city council.
F. Nonpolitical/No Compensation: The members of the committee shall be selected without regard to political affiliations and shall serve without
compensation.
G. Organization: At the first meeting of each fiscal year or as soon thereafter as practicable, the members of the committee shall meet and organize to
elect a chairperson, vice chairperson, and fill such other offices as determined necessary. The chairperson shall preside at meetings of the committee.
The vice chairperson shall, when the chairperson is absent, perform the duties of the chairperson. The committee shall also elect a secretary from
within its membership, who shall be responsible for meeting minutes. The chairperson shall be elected annually.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 27/303
H. Committee Terms: Each member of the committee shall serve a term of three (3) years or until his or her successor is appointed and confirmed.
Vacancies arising in any member's position shall be filled for the remaining term of the member originally appointed. Initial appointments to the
committee shall be made as follows: one or more one year terms; one or more two (2) year terms; and one or more three (3) year terms. All additional
appointments shall be made at the discretion of the mayor (evenly staggered if there are fewer members). Committee members may be reappointed to
serve additional terms. (Ord. 1327, 7-6-2016)
2-8-4: DUTIES:
The committee shall:
A. Hold meetings at least four (4) times per year;
B. Consider and address priorities introduced by city council and the city administration;
C. Consider and track impact of city parking policies on city finances and downtown merchants, with the goal of economic viability for the city of Sandpoint;
D. Provide a forum for dialog and public input;
E. Provide mechanisms appropriate to ascertain facts and discern views;
F. Broaden citizen participation in self-government;
G. Propose to the city council, on an annual basis, a set of recommended projects to improve the downtown parking environment, guidance on parking
rate setting, and other public policy recommendations concerning the downtown parking system;
H. Review complaints and issues that have been submitted to the city or to the designated parking services manager.
1. Recommend policy changes to improve parking system management and service to city council.
2. Review and waive fine if committee determines a fine has been improperly charged. (Ord. 1327, 7-6-2016)
2-8-5: SEVERABILITY:
A. That any provision of this code found to be inconsistent with this chapter be and the same is hereby repealed.
B. Should any provision of this chapter be deemed unlawful or unconstitutional, such finding shall not affect the remaining provisions of this chapter. (Ord.
1327, 7-6-2016)

E. Provide mechanisms appropriate to ascertain facts and discern views;
F. Broaden citizen participation in self-government;
G. Promote and conduct educational programs for city staff regarding ADA accessibility; and
H. Review complaints and issues that have been submitted to the city or to the designated ADA coordinator. (Ord. 1340, 12-7-2016)
Title 3
BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
GENERAL LICENSE REGULATIONS1
3-1-1: APPLICATIONS:
Applications for all licenses and permits required by this code shall be made in writing to the city clerk, unless otherwise specifically provided by law. Each
application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or license desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee to be paid; and
each application shall contain such additional information as may be required by the issuing official. (Revised Code 1958)
3-1-2: PERSON SUBJECT TO LICENSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 29/303
Whenever in this code a license is required for the maintenance, operation or conduct of any business or establishment, or for doing business or engaging
in any activity or occupation, any person or corporation shall be subject to the requirement if by himself or through an agent, employee or partner, he holds
himself forth as being engaged in the business or occupation; or solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively; or performs or attempts to perform any
part of such business or occupation in the city. (Revised Code 1958)
3-1-3: FORMS:
Forms for all licenses and permits, and applications therefor, shall be prepared and kept on file by the city clerk. (Revised Code 1958)
3-1-4: SIGNATURES:
Each license or permit issued shall bear the signatures of the city clerk and such other official, if any, as may be required. (Revised Code 1958)
3-1-5: INVESTIGATIONS:
Upon the receipt of an application for a license or permit where laws of the city necessitate an inspection or investigation before the issuance of such
permit or license, the city clerk shall refer such application to the proper officer for making such investigation within forty eight (48) hours of the time of
receipt. The officer charged with the duty of making the investigation or inspection shall make a report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within ten (10) days
after receiving the application or a copy thereof. (Revised Code 1958)
3-1-6: TERMINATION OF LICENSE:
All annual licenses shall terminate on the last day of the calendar year, where no provision to the contrary is made. (Revised Code 1958)
3-1-7: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business, and no permit shall be issued for any thing, or act, if the premises and building to be used for
the purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of the city. No such license or permit shall be issued for the conduct of any business or performance
of any act which would involve a violation of the zoning regulations of the city (title 9 of this code). (Revised Code 1958)
3-1-8: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
In the absence of any provision to the contrary, the location of any licensed business or occupation, or of any permitted act, may be changed, provided ten
(10) days' notice thereof is given to the city clerk. (Revised Code 1958)
3-1-9: POSTING OF LICENSE:
It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in the city to keep his license posted in a prominent place on the premises used for such
business at all times. (Revised Code 1958)
3-1-10: LICENSE FEES:
In the absence of specific provisions to the contrary, all fees and charges for licenses or permits shall be paid in advance at the time application therefor is
made to the city clerk. Licenses shall be required for the following activities and businesses upon payment of the fee set forth in the section indicated:
Beer Section 3-2-5
Dogs Subsection 5-4-4C
Liquor Section 3-2-5
Merchant security guards Section 3-6-2
Pawnbroker Section 3-5-2
Secondhand store Section 3-5-2
Taxicabs and limousines Section 6-4-4
Vacation home rental Subsection 3-12-4A1a
(Revised Code 1958; amd. 1983 Code; Ord. 807, 6-17-1985; Ord. 884, 5-15-1989; Ord. 938, 1-18-1994; Ord. 1121, 11-17-2004; Ord. 1128, 2-16-2005;
Ord. 1174, 5-16-2007)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 30/303
Chapter 2
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE REGULATIONS
3-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
BEER: Any beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or decoction of barley, malt and/or other ingredients in drinkable water.
LIQUOR: Includes all intoxicating liquors whether sold, consumed or dispensed alone or mixed with or combined with some other substance suitable for
consumption.
OFF PREMISES SALES: Includes all sales, transfers, distribution and dissemination of beer, wine and/or liquor by a person or establishment with the
intent and for the purpose that said substance shall not be consumed on the premises of the person or establishment selling, distributing, transferring or
dispensing the same.
ON PREMISES: Refers to the sale, transfer, distribution or dissemination of beer, wine and/or liquor by a person with the intent that the consumer or
purchaser shall consume the same on the premises of the person or business establishment selling, transferring, distributing or disseminating the
substance.
ON PREMISES SECONDARY TO RESTAURANT: Those sales of beer, wine and/or liquor sold, transferred, distributed or dispensed with the intent and
with provisions available that the substance will be consumed by the purchaser or available for consumption on the premises of the person or business
establishment selling, transferring, distributing or dispensing the same wherein the sale, transfer, distribution or dispensation is not the primary business
activity of the person or business establishment so doing and where said person or business establishment functions as a "restaurant" as hereinafter
defined and the sale, transfer, distribution or dispensation of the beer, wine and/or liquor is secondary to the restaurant business. Such activity shall
constitute a separate classification governed by the provisions hereinafter described as applicable to sale of wine, beer and/or liquor secondary to
restaurant.
PERSON: Includes an individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation or any group or combination acting as a unit and includes the plural as well as
the singular unless the intent to give a more limited meaning is disclosed by the context in which said term is used.
RESTAURANT: As applicable to those licenses for the sale of wine, beer and/or liquor secondary to restaurant: any place of business commonly known
and recognized as a restaurant having a kitchen and cooking facilities for the preparation of meals and space and accommodation where, in consideration
for payment, meals are regularly served to the public for consumption on the premises. The term "restaurant" does not include lunch counters, lunch
stands, coffee shops, cafeterias, short order cafes, luncheonettes, sandwich stands, soda fountains or services of fry orders or short orders. A place of
business shall not be deemed a restaurant under the terms of this chapter unless the principal business conducted thereat is the regular preparation,
service and sale of meals to the public for consumption on the premises during all hours and times that the place of business is open for business.
WINE: Any alcoholic beverage containing not more than fourteen percent (14%) alcohol by volume obtained by the fermentation of the natural sugar
content of fruits or other agricultural products containing sugar. (Ord. 692, 11-19-1979)
3-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, at retail, wine, beer and/or liquor within the corporate limits of the city without having first procured a license
therefor as hereinafter set forth. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the state or its agencies. (Ord. 692, 11-19-1979)
The application for license shall be in writing, signed and sworn to by the applicant upon an application form furnished by, and available through, the office
of the city clerk. Such application shall be filed by the city clerk and processed pursuant to section 3-2-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 857, 12-21-1987)
3-2-2-1: CATERING PERMITS:
A. Application:
1. An alcohol beverage catering permit is a permit issued pursuant to this section, that authorizes the permittee to serve and sell liquor by the drink,
beer and wine, or beer, or wine, at a party, festival or convention, as defined by Idaho Code, not to exceed five (5) consecutive days, with an option
to request one permit extension on the same terms and conditions as the original permit, which extension may be issued or denied at the sole and
absolute discretion of the original issuing entity. An alcohol beverage catering permit shall be limited to authorization to sell liquor, or beer or wine, or
any combination thereof, based upon the type of license which the applicant possesses. Applications for such permit shall be made to the city clerk,
on such form as prescribed by the city, which shall contain at a minimum, but not limited to, the following information:
a. The name and address of the applicant and the number of his state liquor, beer or wine license.
b. The dates and hours during which the original permit is to be effective, not to exceed five (5) consecutive days.
c. The names of the organizations, groups, or persons sponsoring the event.
d. The address at which the liquor, beer or wine is to be served and, if a public building, the rooms in which the liquor, beer or wine is to be served.
2. The application shall be verified by the applicant and filed with the city clerk. A filing fee in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each day the
permit is to be effective shall be paid to the treasury of the city which shall not be refunded in any event. The permit shall be valid only within the city.
No alcohol beverage catering permit issued pursuant to this section shall be used on a licensed premises. An alcohol beverage catering permit
issued pursuant to this section shall only be exercised by the licensee on record.
B. Filing Of Application; Approval: Upon the filing of an application for an alcohol beverage catering permit, the city clerk receiving the application shall,
upon the advice and recommendation of the police chief and fire chief or their designated representatives, approve or deny the application and indicate
the determination on the face of the application by endorsement signed by the clerk. The police chief and fire chief are authorized to endorse an
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 31/303
application for an alcohol beverage catering permit with sufficient conditions to ensure public safety. Copies of the application with signed
endorsements thereon shall be delivered immediately to the police chief, the director of the Idaho state police, and the applicant, and a signed copy
retained by the clerk. An application approved in this matter shall constitute a permit.
C. Idaho Winery License: Any person who is the holder of an Idaho winery license shall be eligible to obtain an alcohol beverage catering permit. Two (2)
or more wineries may use a winery's licensed premises to host an event under an alcohol beverage catering permit to serve and sell their respective
wines at that event. (Ord. 1329, 7-6-2016)
3-2-3: QUALIFICATIONS FOR LICENSE:
An applicant for a license shall possess all of the qualifications necessary to obtain a license from the director of the department of law enforcement of the
state as prescribed by the laws of the state1, and shall maintain qualifications throughout the period for which such license is issued. The possession of
licenses regularly issued by the department of law enforcement and Bonner County, shall be prima facie evidence of the applicant's qualification to receive
a license hereunder. (Ord. 692, 11-19-1979; amd. 1983 Code)
3-2-4: LICENSE PROCEDURES:
A. Processing Of Application For Issuance Of Renewal Of License: Upon filing of such application, the city clerk shall, within a period of three (3) days,
advise the applicant in writing of its approval or denial.
B. Issuance Of License: Upon filing the application for a license, production of evidence as required in section 3-2-3 of this chapter as to the qualifications
of the applicant, and payment of the required fees provided for herein, the clerk shall issue to the applicant a license to sell beer, wine and/or liquor at
retail within the city for a calendar year beginning January 1 or for the remainder thereof.
C. Transfer Of License: Licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be transferable. The possession of a transferred license regularly issued
by the department of law enforcement and Bonner County, shall be prima facie evidence of the applicant's qualification to receive a license transfer
hereunder. However, no license shall be transferred to any other person until such person has applied for such transfer on an application as provided
by the city clerk, and has been found to be qualified to obtain such license under the provisions of this chapter. Upon the approval of the transfer of any
license as herein provided, the city clerk shall charge and collect the required fee provided for herein.
D. Procedure In The Event Of Denial: In the event such application is denied, such notification of denial shall specify:
1. The statutes, ordinances and standards used in evaluating the application.
2. The reasons for denial.
3. The actions, if any, the applicant could take to obtain the license, transfer or renewal thereof.
An applicant denied a license, transfer or renewal thereof may appeal the city clerk's decision to the city council within thirty (30) days after mailing to
the applicant by the city of such notice of denial. The manner of such appeal shall be consistent with that relating to review of a contested case
pursuant to Idaho Code title 67, chapter 52. (Ord. 857, 12-21-1987)
3-2-5: LICENSE AND TRANSFER FEES:
License and transfer fees, as established by resolution adopted by the city council, shall be paid at the time application is made for, and as a condition
precedent to, issuance or transfer of a license. (Ord. 857, 12-21-1987)
3-2-6: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
Licenses to sell at retail, dispense or serve beer within the city limits shall not exceed twenty two (22) in number at any one time while the population of the
said city shall be four thousand five hundred (4,500) or less and for each five hundred (500) population in addition to four thousand five hundred (4,500),
an additional one license only, may be issued; provided, however, that the provisions herein shall not apply to the state or its agencies and shall not apply
to the retail sale of beer not to be consumed on the premises where sold; and, further, shall not apply to those licenses applied for and issued for the sale
of beer secondary to "restaurant" as above described. (Ord. 692, 11-19-1979)
3-2-7: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
Any license issued for sale of wine, beer or liquor secondary to restaurant shall be deemed to permit only the sale, dispensing and distribution of beer,
wine and liquor to be consumed on premises of the restaurant business. (Ord. 692, 11-19-1979)
3-2-8: SALE HOURS RESTRICTED:
It is unlawful for any person to sell beer and wine between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and liquor to be consumed on
the premises between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. In addition to the days on which liquor may be sold pursuant to title
23, chapter 9 of the Idaho Code, liquor may be sold on Sunday, Memorial Day and Thanksgiving. (Ord. 1126, 2-2-2005)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 32/303
3-2-9: OPEN CONTAINER LAW:
A. No person in a motor vehicle, while the vehicle is on a public highway or the right of way of a public highway in the city, may drink or possess any open
beverage containing alcoholic liquor, beer, or wine, unless such person is a passenger in the passenger area of a limousine, or in the living quarters of
a recreational vehicle. Violation of this section is a misdemeanor for the individual in actual physical control of the vehicle pursuant to section 18-8004,
Idaho Code, and an infraction for other individuals violating this section. (Ord. 1295, 2-5-2014)
B. It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or consume beer, wine or any other intoxicating beverage or to have in their possession any open bottle, can
or other container containing such beer, wine or other intoxicating beverage while on a sidewalk or anywhere within the public street right of way or in
any public park within the city, except as follows:
1. Consumption of alcoholic beverages is allowed in Farmin Park and at War Memorial Field when purchased on site from an authorized vendor with a
valid alcohol beverage catering permit issued by the city for events approved by the parks and recreation director or city council, as applicable.
Those consuming alcoholic beverages must remain in specific areas of the park designated for alcoholic beverage consumption. In all cases, they
must remain within the inner boundary of the park's fence or curb and not inhibit the use of the sidewalk by other persons. (Ord. 1297, 3-19-2014)
3-2-10: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The right to revoke a license issued pursuant to the provisions herein contained shall at all times remain vested in the mayor and city council, and the
mayor and the city council may, as hereinafter provided, revoke or cancel any license for fraud or misrepresentation in its procurement or for the violation
of any of the provisions of this chapter or for any conduct or act of the licensee or his employees or any conduct or act permitted by him or them on the
premises where such business is conducted or in connection therewith or adjacent thereto tending to render such business or such premises where the
same is conducted as a public nuisance or a menace to the health, peace, safety or general welfare of the city and its citizens; provided, however, that
revocation or suspension of the state license by the director of the department of law enforcement shall be deemed prima facie evidence for the revocation
and/or suspension of the license issued herein. If the mayor and the city council shall, for any reason, deem revocation, cancellation or suspension of the
license appropriate, the licensee shall be afforded a hearing before the city council and mayor, together with the right of representation at licensee's
expense and choosing, and the city council and mayor, through the city clerk, shall provide written notice to the licensee of said hearing setting forth the
time, place and date for said hearing. Only after such hearing is held or waived by the licensee, shall the license in question be suspended, canceled or
revoked. (Ord. 692, 11-19-1979; amd. 1983 Code; Ord. 857, 12-21-1987)
3-2-11: PENALTY:
Except as otherwise provided herein, any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or fails to comply with any of the terms and conditions
of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, as provided in Idaho Code 50-302. (Ord. 1295, 2-5-2014)
Chapter 3
AMUSEMENTS
(Rep. by Ord. 806, 6-17-1985)
Chapter 4
PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
3-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this Chapter shall be as follows:
APPLICANT: Each natural person applying for registration pursuant to this Chapter.
CANVASSER OR SOLICITOR: Any individual, whether a resident of the City or not, traveling either by foot, or any type of conveyance, from place to place
or from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any
nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for
sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not; provided, that such definition shall include
any person who for himself, or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room,
lodginghouse, apartment, shop or any other place within the City for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery.
PEDDLER: Any person, whether a resident of the City or not, traveling by foot, motor vehicle or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from
house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm
products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers; provided, that one who solicits
orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this Chapter shall be
deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this Chapter. The word "peddler" shall include the words "hawker" and "huckster".
TRANSIENT MERCHANT: Any person, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the City or not, who engages in a
temporary business of selling, and delivering goods, wares and merchandise and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, or occupies any
building, structure, motor vehicles, tent, railroad boxcar, or boat, public rooms in hotels, lodging houses, apartments, shops or any streets, alleys or other
places for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction; provided, that such definition shall not be
construed to include any person who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 33/303
securing orders for further delivery only. The term "transient merchant" shall include the terms "itinerant merchant" and "itinerant vendor". (Ord. 886, 6-19-
1989)
3-4-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any canvasser or solicitor, peddler, or transient merchant as the same are herein defined, to engage in such business within the
corporate limits of the City without first registering therefor in compliance with the provisions of this Chapter. Registration issued pursuant to this Chapter
shall not be transferable, nor valid after the end of either: a) the length of time for which the right to do business is requested, or, b) the calendar year in
which the application for registration was approved, whichever is the shorter time period. (Ord. 886, 6-19-1989)
3-4-3: REGISTRATION APPLICATION:
Applicants for registration under this Chapter must file with the City Clerk an application furnished by the City, which shall contain, but not necessarily be
limited to, the following information:
A. The name of the applicant. If the applicant is employed by an association, company, corporation or individual, its name shall be stated with the name of
each person who will be soliciting in the City in its behalf together with credentials establishing the exact relationship;
B. The applicant's place and date of birth;
C. The applicant's social security number;
D. The applicant's driver's license number;
E. The applicant's permanent home address, permanent mailing address, permanent telephone number, full local address and local telephone number;
F. A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two inches
by two inches (2" x 2") showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner;
G. A brief description of the nature of the business and goods to be sold. If goods are products of a farm or orchard, the name of the producer;
H. Proposed method of operation;
I. The length of time for which the right to do business is requested;
J. The applicant's Idaho State sales tax certificate or temporary sales tax permit;
K. If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the vehicle including the license number;
L. The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or
products are located at the time such application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery;
M. When food or other products for human consumption are to be sold, a certification by the applicable health agency shall be required prior to issuance of
a registration;
N. A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of any misdemeanor or felony, the date and nature of the offense and the
punishment or penalty assessed therefor;
O. For purposes of conducting the investigation provided for herein, each applicant shall sign a waiver authorizing the Chief of Police or his designated
agent to conduct the investigation including but not limited to a criminal history background check through local, State or National law enforcement
agencies. (Ord. 886, 6-19-1989)
3-4-4: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
Upon receipt of a completed registration application, the City Clerk shall refer it to the Chief of Police who shall cause an investigation to be conducted
within five (5) days to determine the validity and completeness of the information presented on the application, thereafter endorsing upon the application
his approval or disapproval of the application.
If the application is approved, the applicant shall be so notified by the City Clerk, and, upon payment of the prescribed registration fee, a registration shall
be issued. Such registration shall show the name, address and photograph of the applicant, the kind of goods to be sold or the type of sales to be solicited
thereunder, the amount of the fee paid, the date of issuance and the date of expiration, and the license number and other identifying description of any
vehicle used. A permanent record of all licenses issued shall be kept by the City Clerk.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 34/303
If the application is denied, the City Clerk shall provide written notification to the applicant, providing the reasons therefor, and advising the applicant of
appeal procedures. (Ord. 886, 6-19-1989)
3-4-5: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Before any registration as provided herein shall be issued for engaging in the business of peddler, solicitor or canvasser, or transient merchant as defined
in this Chapter, every business, firm, company, corporation or individual which has one or more employees or agents acting in such capacity shall file with
the City a surety bond covering all such employees or agents and running to the City, or a cashier's check, in the amount and pursuant to the procedure to
be established by resolution adopted by the City Council. (Ord. 886, 6-19-1989)
3-4-6: REGISTRATION FEE:
Registration fees, shall be payable in advance, in the amount and pursuant to the procedure to be established by resolution adopted by the City Council.
(Ord. 886, 6-19-1989)
3-4-7: EXHIBITION OF REGISTRATION:
The registration issued to the applicant hereunder shall be exhibited in a conspicuous place if the applicant is using a vehicle or a building in his business
and otherwise must be kept on the person and exhibited at any time upon request. (Ord. 886, 6-19-1989)
3-4-8: UNLAWFUL CONDUCT:
No applicant who is registered with the City pursuant to this Chapter shall:
A. Fail to advise the City Clerk of having knowingly made any false statement on an application for registration hereunder;
B. Enter upon any premises where the same is posted with a sign stating "No Solicitation Allowed" or "No Peddlers Allowed" or other words to that effect;
C. Represent the issuance of any registration under this Chapter as an endorsement or recommendation of the solicitation;
D. Misrepresent the purpose of the solicitation;
E. Misrepresent the affiliation of those engaged in the solicitation;
F. Engage in any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement in the course of carrying on the solicitation;
G. Make physical contact with the person being solicited unless that person's permission is obtained;
H. Continue efforts to solicit from an individual once that individual informs the solicitor that he does not wish to give anything or to buy anything from that
solicitor;
I. Engage in any peddler's or transient merchant's activities on any City property or right of way or in any area within the City for which the City has
previously granted a concession. (Ord. 886, 6-19-1989)
3-4-9: APPEAL FROM DENIAL OF REGISTRATION:
An applicant aggrieved by the denial of the City to issue a registration under this Chapter shall have the right of appeal to the City Council. Such appeal
shall be filed with the City Clerk within five (5) days from the date of denial and must be in writing setting forth the reasons such registration should not
have been denied. The City Council shall hear the appeal within fourteen (14) days after the filing thereof, and shall render its decision immediately
following the hearing. The decision of the majority of the Council shall be final. Appeal of the Council's decision may be made in accordance with Idaho
law. (Ord. 886, 6-19-1989)
3-4-10: REVOCATION OF REGISTRATION:
The City Council shall have the power to revoke any registration granted in accordance with this Chapter for any violation of this Chapter. (Ord. 886, 6-19-
1989)
3-4-11: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this Chapter shall not apply to the following:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 35/303
A. The City, its agents and concessionaires;
B. Any sales under court order;
C. Any bona fide auction sale;
D. Traveling salespersons who exclusively sell to, or solicit orders for future delivery from, local retail businesses, local wholesale firms, local governments
or local schools;
E. The sale of a newspaper subscription in which the seller is the person engaged in both the sale and delivery of the newspaper;
F. The occasional sale of admission to a local function or fund raising sales by recognized service clubs or organizations identified by resolution adopted
by the City Council;
G. Contribution solicitation where the person being solicited to contribute personally knows the identity of the person soliciting the contribution, the name of
the group or organization he represents, and the nature of the services performed or offered by the group or organization;
H. The sale of farm or garden products by person producing same; and,
I. Garage, yard or similar sales by individuals at their residence or place of business not exceeding two (2) days in length nor exceeding twice in one
calendar year, which sale shall not include business inventory. (Ord. 886, 6-19-1989)
Chapter 5
SECONDHAND DEALERS AND PAWNBROKERS
3-5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to own, operate or maintain a pawnbroker's business within the boundaries of the city without having first secured a
license and paid the license fee therefor.
Said license shall be obtained from the city clerk in the manner and form prescribed by the provisions set forth elsewhere in this code. (1983 Code)
3-5-2: LICENSE FEE:
The license fee for each pawnbroker's establishment shall be set by resolution of the city council. (Ord. 1117, 8-18-2004)
3-5-3: PAWNBROKERS:
A. Purchase From Minors: It shall be unlawful for any pawnbrokers, or any person, his agents, or employees who conducts the business of lending money
upon a pledge of personal property, to accept any article of personal property, goods, wares or merchandise, as a pledge for a loan from any person
under the age of eighteen (18) years.
B. Register Of Purchases Kept: Every such pawnbroker, or person or his agent or employee conducting such business of lending money on pledge of
personal property, shall keep a substantial and well bound register in which he shall enter at the time of making every such loan upon pledge of
property, by him, his agents, or employees, the following information:
1. The date, hour, and place of pledge and loan.
2. A true and accurate description of each article, so pledged, including the serial number, name of manufacturer, and any other identifying data, as
disclosed upon each article of personal property pledged.
3. The amount loaned for each article.
4. The name, address, date of birth, social security number, or state identification number, together with a physical description of the person pledging
said personal property.
5. Said register entries shall be in duplicate, the copy portion of which shall be submitted by the licensee to the city police department each and every
Friday reflecting that week's purchases and pledges.
All entries shall be made in the English language in a legible manner with ink or typewriter, and said register shall be open to the inspection of the
police of the city, the sheriff of Bonner County, and any other law enforcement officers of the state of Idaho at any and all reasonable times; provided,
further that whenever any such person conducting the business of loaning money upon pledges of personal property, abandons his occupation, as
such, he shall deliver in good condition, to the city clerk a register of the transactions that he has kept during the time that he has pursued said
occupation as a lender of money upon the pledge of personal property, goods, wares, or merchandise. (Ord. 743, 1-19-1981; amd. 1983 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 36/303
3-5-4: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The right to revoke a license issued pursuant to the provisions herein contained shall at all times remain vested in the mayor and city council, and the
mayor and city council may, as hereinafter provided, revoke or cancel any license for fraud or misrepresentation in its procurement or for the violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter or the state criminal code; provided, however, that conviction under the State Criminal Code shall be prima facie
evidence for the revocation and/or suspension of the license issued hereunder.
If the Mayor and the City Council shall, for any reason, deem revocation, cancellation or suspension of the license appropriate, the licensee shall be
afforded a hearing before the City Council and Mayor, together with the right of representation at licensee's expense and choosing. The City Council and
the Mayor, through the City Clerk, shall provide written notice to the licensee of said hearing setting forth the time, place and date for said hearing and
specifying the violation or default, and said license will be revoked or suspended at the expiration of fifteen (15) days unless a hearing is requested by the
licensee in writing and delivered to the City Clerk.
If a hearing is requested by the licensee, the matter shall be heard by the Mayor and Council and a full record of the proceedings will be made by
electronic recording. The decision of the Mayor and Council shall be the final administrative decision available to the licensee. The licensee may appeal
the governing body's decision by filing appropriate proceedings with a court of competent jurisdiction within ten (10) days of the date of said decision. All
costs of appeal, including prepayment of the costs of the transcript of the recorded hearing, shall be borne by the appellant. (1983 Code)
3-5-5: SECONDHAND DEALERS:
A. Purchase From Minors: It shall be unlawful for any person who conducts a business within the City, which business, wholly or in part, consists of buying
used or secondhand articles, goods, wares, or merchandise, or their agents or their employees, to purchase any such used or secondhand property,
goods, wares or merchandise from persons under the age of eighteen (18) years.
B. Register Of Purchases Kept: Every such dealer in used or secondhand property, goods, wares, or merchandise shall keep a substantial and well-bound
register in which he shall enter, at the time of making every such purchase by him, his agents or his employees of such secondhand or used property,
goods, wares or merchandise, the following information:
1. The hour, date and place of purchase.
2. A true and accurate description of each article purchased, including the serial number, name of manufacturer, if any, and other identifying data, as
disclosed upon said article.
3. The amount paid for each article.
4. The name, address, date of birth, social security number, or State identification number from valid identification, together with a physical description
of the seller.
All entries shall be made in the English language in a legible manner with ink or typewriter, and said register shall be open to the inspection of the
police of the City, the Sheriff of Bonner County and any other law enforcement officers of the State of Idaho, at any and all reasonable times;
provided further, that whenever any dealer abandons his occupation as such, he shall deliver in good condition to the City Clerk a register of the
transactions he has kept during the time that he has pursued said occupation, as a dealer in used or secondhand goods, wares, or merchandise in
the City. (Ord. 743, 1-19-1981; 1983 Code)
3-5-6: PENALTY:
Violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor, and any person, or persons violating the provisions of this Chapter, shall,
upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00), together with costs. (Ord. 743, 1-19-1981; 1983 Code)
Chapter 6
MERCHANT SECURITY GUARD BUSINESS
3-6-1: SHORT TITLE:
This Chapter shall be referred to as the MERCHANT SECURITY GUARD BUSINESS ORDINANCE. (Ord. 884, 5-15-1989)
3-6-2: COUNTY ORDINANCE APPLICABLE:

services and patrolmen. (Ord. 884, 5-15-1989)
Chapter 7
GAS FITTERS
(Rep. by Ord. 1121, 11-17-2004)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 37/303
Chapter 8
JUNK YARDS
3-8-1: JUNK YARDS RESTRICTED:
The operation of junk yards and automobile wrecking yards within the limits of the City is deemed detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare,
unless such establishments be regulated as hereinafter provided. (Revised Code 1958; 1983 Code)
3-8-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, conduct or engage in the business of a junk yard or automobile wrecking yard within the limits of the City
unless and until he is issued a permit by the City to engage in, conduct or establish such business or place. (Revised Code 1958; 1983 Code)
3-8-3: LOCATION RESTRICTION:
No junk yard or wrecking yard hereinafter established shall be originally located, conducted or operated within a radius of two hundred (200) yards of any
inhabitable dwelling house, school, church, store, business, tavern or restaurant. (Revised Code 1958; 1983 Code)
3-8-4: MINORS:
