NUISANCES
4-1-1: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
This chapter seeks to assure that public nuisances will be eliminated and abated promptly and efficiently. (Ord. 1129, 2-16-2005)
4-1-2: DECLARATION OF NUISANCE; ACTS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any "responsible party(ies)" (defined as any person or persons, corporation or other legal entity, tenant and lessee using or
occupying a premises) to cause, allow, maintain or permit the existence of any nuisance on any property within the city of Sandpoint. Any or all parties
may be held accountable. The following are hereby declared a public nuisance:
A. Abandoned, partially dismantled, discarded, wrecked, scrapped, or junked vehicles (including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, ATVs,
snowmobiles, motorcycles, campers) or parts thereof or any other vehicle not suitable for road travel specifically any vehicle that does not have affixed
to the vehicle a current state license tag, off road vehicle registration and/or recreational vehicle license, on any property, including public streets,
roads, highways. The absence of a current license from any vehicle shall be presumptive evidence that such vehicle is abandoned, discarded,
scrapped, ruined, or junked.
B. An accumulation of refuse or animal waste, including any carcass of any dead animal of any kind on any property.
C. Broken, discarded, or heavily damaged and unused machinery, equipment, or implements, including furniture or appliances.
D. Condemned, damaged, decayed, dilapidated, unsanitary, unsafe, vermin infested, partially dismantled buildings/structures or buildings/structures in ill
repair, including used or salvaged building supplies.
E. Accumulation of garbage, refuse, trash items, including, but not limited to, metal, glass or tires including any recycling business that allows the
accumulation to constitute a public health and/or safety hazard.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 52/303
F. Weeds deemed noxious by the state of Idaho or the city weed superintendent growing in any lot or tract of land in the city of Sandpoint.
G. Discharge of any offensive matter, including aromas and/or fumes, in residential areas, as well as, placing, throwing, discharging or flowing from any
house or premises of any filthy, putrid, or offensive matter or liquid of any kind.
H. Between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. through six thirty o'clock (6:30) A.M., it shall be unlawful for any person or business to make or cause
loud or offensive noise by means of voice, musical instrument, horn, radio, loudspeaker, sound amplifying equipment, automobile, machinery or power
tools, or any other means which disturbs the peace, quiet, and comfort of any reasonable person of normal sensitivities residing in the area.
I. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or within any unoccupied or
abandoned building, structure or dwelling under his control, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox,
refrigerator or other container which has a door or lid, snaplock or other locking device which may not be released from the inside, without first
removing said door or lid, snaplock or other locking device, or by first fastening, bolting or locking the same in such a manner that it is impossible to
open the same by the use of the hands.
J. The various nuisances described and enumerated in this section shall not be exclusive but shall be in addition to all other nuisances described and
prohibited by this code. (Ord. 1129, 2-16-2005)
4-1-3: EXCEPTIONS:
A. Materials and things described in the foregoing section may be retained within a building or a fence at least six feet (6') high which prevents the view (or
smell) of these things from the street or from other public or private property. The fence must be constructed of wood, masonry, or be a chainlink fence
with sight occluding slats, or be constructed of other materials approved by the building official. However, the fence may not be constructed within the
required front setback and shall comply with all applicable fence requirements.
B. Noise emitting utility work, road maintenance and construction work, and functions at municipal parks or town squares shall be exempt from this
chapter.
C. Authorized city dumps, transfer stations, or landfills shall be exempt from this chapter.
D. Noise from snow removal equipment. (Ord. 1129, 2-16-2005)
4-1-4: STANDARDS FOR ABATEMENT:
A violation shall be considered abated when the offending personal property is either removed from the premises, enclosed inside a building, or screened
from view from both the street and adjoining property and/or odor is eliminated. For weeds, abatement will be satisfied when the weeds have been
effectively sprayed as directed by the city weed superintendent or cut to a height of less than six inches (6"). Temporary measures, such as tarps,
unenclosed or unscreened areas, are not considered abatement. (Ord. 1129, 2-16-2005)
4-1-5: METHODS OF ABATEMENT:
Whenever a violation of this chapter is found, the code enforcement officer or any other official having the responsibility for the enforcement of the city of
Sandpoint ordinances may take one or more of the following actions:
A. Order the violation corrected by the responsible party(ies) by removal and proper disposal of materials within a specified period ranging from one to
thirty (30) days. A notice of violation shall be sent via mailing or hand delivery to the responsible party(ies).
B. If the responsible party(ies) agrees to abate the violation, but is unable to remove and/or dispose of the violation in the time frame specified in the notice
of violation, they may, at the code enforcement officer's discretion, enter into a voluntary nuisance abatement agreement. To secure the voluntary
nuisance abatement agreement, the responsible party(ies) must provide compelling evidence why they seek nuisance abatement relief.
C. Request the city of Sandpoint police department to issue a uniform infraction citation for the violation of this chapter if this is the first violation within two
(2) years or alternatively issue a uniform misdemeanor citation if this a second or subsequent violation within two (2) years.
D. The city of Sandpoint may file a petition for injunctive relief against the property owner in the district court of the state of Idaho for Bonner County
seeking an order compelling compliance with this chapter.
E. Any additional civil remedy available to the city of Sandpoint. (Ord. 1129, 2-16-2005)
4-1-6: VOLUNTARY NUISANCE ABATEMENT AGREEMENT:
The code enforcement officer (see also section 1-6-4 of this code) may secure voluntary nuisance abatement by contracting with the party(ies) responsible
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 53/303
for the violation. The voluntary nuisance abatement agreement is a contract between the city and the party(ies) responsible for the violation under which
such party(ies) agrees to abate the violation within a specified time and according to specified conditions.
A. Time Limit Extension: An extension of the time limit for abatement or a modification of the required corrective action may be granted by the code
enforcement officer. Extension or modification of the voluntary nuisance abatement agreement is allowed if the party(ies) responsible for the violation
has shown due diligence and/or substantial progress in correcting the violation but unforeseen circumstances render abatement under the original
conditions unattainable.
B. Abatement By The City: The city may abate the violation using city forces or contract for abatement if the terms of the voluntary nuisance abatement
agreement are not complied with or in the case were the nuisance constitutes imminent danger to public health and/or safety.
C. Collection Of Costs: If the terms of the voluntary nuisance abatement agreement are not met, the party(ies) responsible for the violation shall be
assessed all costs and expenses of abatement including attorney fees, if incurred. If such expenses are unpaid for thirty (30) days, the fees assessed
may be forwarded to a collection agency to be collected in accordance with Idaho Code or the city may accept a note placing a lien on the property for
the cleanup costs. In addition, if the voluntary nuisance abatement agreement is not completed, all other methods of abatement as listed in this chapter
shall apply. (Ord. 1129, 2-16-2005)
4-1-7: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
A first violation of a provision of this chapter shall be charged as an infraction. The court may assess a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00)
for each violation. Each day that a responsible party(ies) allows a nuisance to continue on property under his or her control may be a separate violation. A
new or subsequent violation within two (2) years may be charged as a misdemeanor with the maximum penalty of three hundred dollars ($300.00) and/or
six (6) months in jail. (Ord. 1129, 2-16-2005)
Chapter 2
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
4-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
GARBAGE: All ashes, cans, rubbish, and other materials, including all putrescible wastes and recognizable industrial by-products. (Ord. 611, 8-18-1977;
1983 Code)
4-2-2: DISPOSAL AND COLLECTION OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE:
A. Manner Of Disposal:
1. All garbage at residences within the City shall be accumulated in watertight receptacles of not more than thirty (30) gallons each and shall be
equipped with two (2) handles and with tight covers. Such containers shall be so constructed of a material in such a manner as to be strong, not
easily corrodible and rodent and insect.proof.
2. All other trash and garbage shall be accumulated in commercial retainers and receptacles of larger than thirty (30) gallons each and shall be
equipped with tight covers and so constructed as to be strong, watertight, not easily corrodible and rodent proof.
3. Trash such as boxes, papers, grass clippings, tree cuttings and odd articles shall be crushed and boxed, or bundled in lengths not to exceed five feet
(5') and not to exceed fifty (50) pounds in weight. Containers for trash need not be watertight, but should have handles. Any items in excess of these
limitations shall be considered a special haul.
B. Collection Provisions: All trash and garbage shall be collected by the City or the contract collector as herein provided. The Mayor and City Council shall
provide for the collection of garbage and refuse either by the City, or contract with the lowest or responsible bidder for such time as the Mayor and
Council may direct after advertising in the official newspaper of the Municipality for bids.
C. Disposal Site: The disposal of all garbage, trash, debris, and offal, pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter, shall be at a landfill designated for such
use and approved by the State. (Ord. 611, 8-18-1977; 1983 Code)
4-2-3: RATES AND CHARGES:
A. The Mayor and City Council shall fix rates and may fix supplementary rules and regulations by resolution. Three (3) copies, duly certified by the City
Clerk, of said resolution shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk for use and examination of and by the public.
B. The occupant of every dwelling and the operator of every commercial establishment within the City shall be assessed at least the minimum charge
provided in the rate schedule fixed by the Mayor and City Council for the collection and disposal of garbage, trash and other waste materials.
C. The City may levy a special assessment against the premises for failure to pay charges and delinquency charges fixed by resolution of the Mayor and
City Council, in the same manner provided by law for the foreclosure and collection of other City special assessments. (Ord. 611, 8-18-1977; 1983
Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 54/303
4-2-4: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. Burning Garbage: It shall be unlawful for any person to burn garbage or refuse within the City limits, except waste papers, boxes, brush, grass, weeds,
and cuttings from trees, lawns or gardens, which may be burned only at times designated by the Fire Chief or by permit issued by the Fire Chief.
B. Accumulation Of Garbage Or Trash: It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor to accumulate trash and garbage or to violate any of the prohibitory or
mandatory regulations and other rules authorized and established by this Chapter. (Ord. 611, 8-18-1977; 1983 Code)
Chapter 3
FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION
ARTICLE A. FIRE DEPARTMENT
4-3A-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby created a Fire Department which shall consist of a Fire Chief and such other personnel as may be provided for by the City Council.
(Revised Code 1958)
4-3A-2: DUTIES OF MEMBERS:
It shall be the duty of members of the Fire Department to provide for the immediate answering of all fire calls and to fight all fires in the best and most
modern available methods. Members shall see to the care and maintenance of all firefighting equipment and have such equipment in constant workable
condition at all times. (Revised Code 1958)
4-3A-3: FIRE PREVENTION:
Every possible action shall be taken by the members of the Fire Department to eliminate fire hazards and to provide for fire prevention methods and
operations within the City. (Revised Code 1958)
4-3A-4: VOLUNTEER MEMBERS:
Any volunteer members of the Fire Department shall conduct themselves in the same manner and under the same rules and regulations as regular
members of the Department. They shall respond to all fire calls according to a schedule prescribed by the Chief of the Fire Department and they shall
attend all meetings and drills called by the Chief. (Revised Code 1958)
ARTICLE B. FIREWORKS
4-3B-1: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. It is unlawful for any person to possess, sell, give away or discharge any firecrackers or fireworks of any kind in the City except those fireworks
specifically approved by provisions of the Idaho Code.
B. It is unlawful for any person to possess, sell, give away or discharge any firecrackers or fireworks of any kind in the City parks, and all City-owned or
leased property, except those fireworks specifically approved under the provisions of Section 4-3B-2 of this Article. (Ord. 1027, 7-21-1999)
4-3B-2: PUBLIC DISPLAY PERMITS:
The Fire Chief is hereby authorized and empowered to issue written permits for the public display or exhibition of fireworks within the territorial limits of the
City. Such permits must specify the time and place for the giving of such public display or exhibition and shall prescribe the conditions governing the
conduct of the same. A reasonable fee for issuance of such permit shall be established by the City Clerk. (Ord. 232, 9-23-1949; amd. 1983 Code)
4-3B-3: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the members of the Police Department and Chief of the Fire Department of the City to take such steps as may be necessary for the
enforcement of this Article. (Ord. 232, 9-23-1949; amd. 1983 Code)
4-3B-4: PENALTY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 55/303
Any person violating the provisions of this Article shall be subject to a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) and costs of prosecution, or by
imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. 232, 9-23-1949; amd. 1983 Code)
Chapter 4
NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL ACT
4-4-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL ACT. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-2: PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVE:
It is hereby determined and declared to be necessary and conducive to and for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the public and inhabitants
of the city to provide for the abatement of noxious weeds from both vacant and occupied properties located within the city. The objectives of this chapter
are to:
A. Define noxious weeds; legal requirements, duties and responsibilities of landowners, citizens and city; prevent the accumulation of noxious weeds as
defined in this chapter which would otherwise pose a nuisance and fire hazard; to provide the statutory and financial means of the control of noxious
weeds wherever such noxious weeds occur within the city;
B. Provide an equitable means for the abatement of any such nuisance; and
C. Enhance the safety and beauty of the city. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-3: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall be construed as specified either in this section, or as specified in the
international building code, the international fire code, promulgated by the International Code Council and the uniform code for the abatement of
dangerous buildings, promulgated by the International Conference of Building Officials, as adopted by the city. Where terms are not defined, they shall
have their ordinarily accepted meanings within the context within which they are used. The most recent edition of "Webster's New International Dictionary
Of The English Language, Unabridged", shall be construed as providing ordinarily accepted meanings. Words used in the singular include the plural and
the plural the singular. Words in the masculine gender include the feminine and the feminine the masculine. The following terms are defined in this section
as follows:
AGENCY: The city of Sandpoint, any other local government unit or entity including, but not limited to, counties and any legal subdivision thereof, drainage
districts, irrigation districts, canal companies, highway districts, fire districts, and any special taxing district.
CITY WEED SUPERINTENDENT: The city of Sandpoint city fire department chief, or any other person duly appointed by the mayor.
CONTAINMENT: The halting of the spread of a weed infestation beyond specified boundaries.
CONTROL AUTHORITY: The city weed superintendent or his duly designated agent.
ERADICATION: The complete elimination of all aboveground plant growth deemed to be a noxious weed, nuisance and/or fire hazard.
LAND: All soil or water or other growing medium.
LANDOWNER: A. The person who holds legal title to the land except that portion for which another person has the right to exclude others from possession
of that parcel;
B. A person with an interest in a parcel of land such that the person has the right to exclude others from possession of the parcel.
NOXIOUS WEED: A. Any plant having the potential to cause injury to public health, crops, livestock, land or other property; which is designated as noxious
by the director of agriculture;
B. Any plant or natural vegetative matter as such, but not limited to, hay, grass, straw, weeds or other similar combustible or flammable plant material
when the same endangers the health, safety and welfare of the public or is liable to be fired.
OWNER: The title holder or purchaser entitled to possession of any tract of real property.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, firm, corporation, company, society, association or any other entity.
PREVENTION: A. Any action that reduces the potential for the introduction or establishment of a plant species in areas not currently invested with that
species;
B. Any action that reduces the potential for the uncontrolled growth of any "noxious weed" defined hereunder from becoming a nuisance and/or fire
hazard.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 56/303
WEED CONTROL: Any or all of the following: prevention, restoration, eradication, modified treatment within the city limits. (Ord. 1075, 12-18-2002)
4-4-4: CITY'S DUTIES:
A. City Control Authority: The city control authority shall:
1. Carry out the duties and responsibilities vested in the city under this chapter and rules and regulations prescribed by the city council; and
2. Establish and maintain a coordinated program for control of noxious weeds as defined in this chapter in the city; designate or employ a city weed
superintendent who shall be qualified to detect and treat noxious weeds as defined in this chapter; and
3. Designate one of its city council members of the liaison between the city weed superintendent and any other agency; and
4. Provide operational and educational funds for the city weed superintendent.
B. Publish Notice: A general notice for control of noxious weeds shall be published annually in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. Failure to
publish the notice for control or serve individual notices herein provided does not relieve any person from full compliance with this chapter and
regulations hereunder. In all cases said published notice shall be deemed legal and sufficient notice.
C. Serve Individual Notices: The city shall cause individual notices on a form prescribed by the city weed superintendent to be served upon the landowner
and where possible on the occupier of the land giving specific instructions when and how certain named noxious weeds as defined under this chapter
are to be controlled. The individual notice shall also contain information concerning the right to appeal pursuant to sections 4-4-6 and 4-4-9 of this
chapter.
D. City Weed Superintendent: The city weed superintendent or his duly designated agent shall:
1. Examine all land within the city for the purposes of determining whether the provisions of this chapter and the rules and regulations of the city weed
superintendent have been complied with; and
2. Compile data and submit reports as the city council may require; and
3. Implement enforcement action as outlined in this chapter; and
4. Consult, advise and provide direction on matters pertaining to the most effective and most practical methods of noxious weed control; and
5. Investigate or aid in the investigation and prosecution of any violation of the provisions of this Chapter.
E. Failure To Control; Remedies: Whenever the landowner of any non-Federal land on which noxious weeds as described under this Chapter are present
has neglected or failed to initiate control as required pursuant to this Chapter within ten (10) working days from receipt of an individual notice given
pursuant to this Section, the City having jurisdiction shall have proper control methods used on such land, including necessary destruction of crops,
and shall advise the landowner of the cost incurred in connection with such operation. The cost of any such control, plus a civil penalty, as provided in
Section 4-4-7 of this Chapter, shall be at the expense of the landowner. If the costs have not been paid to the City within sixty (60) days, the Control
Authority may direct that suit be brought in a court of competent jurisdiction for the unpaid charges. On private lands if unpaid for sixty (60) days or
longer, the amount of such expense may become a lien upon the property; and thereafter the lien shall be subject to collection by the City by sale of the
property in the same manner as for delinquent taxes. Nothing contained in this Section shall be construed to require satisfaction of the imposed
obligation by the sale of property or to bar the application of any other available remedy. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-5: LANDOWNER AND CITIZEN'S DUTIES:
A. It shall be the duty and responsibility of all landowners to control noxious weeds as defined by this Chapter on their land and property in accordance
with this Chapter and the rules and regulations herein.
B. The cost of controlling noxious weeds as defined by this Chapter shall be the obligation of the landowner or the rightful occupier of said land.
C. Noxious weed control must be for prevention, eradication or restoration. However, the City may modify and waive certain eradication requirements upon
the determination of eradication being an unreasonable short-term prevention.
D. The landowner and/or occupier shall reimburse the City for work done, plus a civil penalty, as provided in Section 4-4-7 of this Chapter, because of
failure to comply with a ten (10) day notice as outlined in this Chapter. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-6: CITY POWERS:
The City Weed Control Authority is authorized to:
A. Control Of Noxious Weeds: Have noxious weeds as defined by this Chapter controlled without cost to the landowner, notwithstanding any other
provision of this Chapter relating to payment of costs.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 57/303
B. Infestation Or Nuisance:
1. Control Or Containment: To put into immediate operation the required means for control or containment of such noxious weeds when it is found that
there is an infestation or nuisance of noxious weeds beyond the ability of the landowner to control.
2. Eradication Of Noxious Weeds: Any real property which is determined, after inspection by the Weed Superintendent or his authorized representative,
to be unsafe, dangerous or hazardous because of the accumulation of noxious weeds, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be
abated by the eradication of such noxious weeds in accordance with the procedure specified in this Section.
C. Inspections: The City Weed Superintendent is hereby authorized to make such inspections and take actions as may be required to enforce the
provisions of this Chapter.
D. Inspection Of Real Property: Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of this Chapter or, whenever the City Weed
Superintendent or his authorized representative has reasonable cause to believe that there exists on real property any condition or violation of this
Chapter which makes such real property unsafe, dangerous and/or hazardous, the Weed Superintendent or his authorized representative may enter
upon such real property at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon the Weed Superintendent by this Section;
provided, that if such real property be occupied he shall first present proper credentials and request entry; the Weed Superintendent or their duly
authorized representative shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry.
E. Dissatisfaction With Amount Of Charge: If any person shall be dissatisfied with the amount of any charge made against it by a city control authority for
control work or for the purchase of materials or the use of equipment he/she may within thirty (30) days after being advised of the amount of the charge
file a protest with the city weed superintendent.
F. Dissatisfaction With Control Measures: If any person shall be dissatisfied with the control measures used or the manner in which control is conducted
upon his property, he may within thirty (30) days file a protest with the city weed superintendent. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
G. Serving Notice: Any person served with an individual notice may within two (2) working days of receipt of the notice appeal to the city mayor. A hearing
shall be set by the mayor within five (5) working days after receipt of the notice of appeal. Notice of the hearing shall be sent by the mayor to the
appellant. (Ord. 1274, 7-18-2012)
H. Board Of Appeals: In order to provide for reasonable interpretation of the provisions of this chapter and to hear appeals provided for hereunder, there
may be impaneled by the mayor, upon the request of an appellant, a board of appeals consisting of three (3) members who are qualified by experience
and training to pass upon matters pertaining to noxious weeds as defined under this chapter and their eradication. The weed superintendent shall be
an ex officio member of and shall act as secretary to the board. The board of appeals shall be appointed by the mayor and shall hold office at the
mayor's pleasure. The board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the
appellant with a duplicate copy to the weed superintendent. Appeals to the board shall be processed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
Copies of all rules or regulations adopted by the board shall be delivered to the fire chief and city weed superintendent who shall make them freely
available to the public.
I. Findings/Conclusions: Appeals of the board of review shall be brought before the city council. The city council's findings/conclusions and order shall be
final and binding on all parties. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-7: VIOLATIONS, PENALTIES:
A. Any person knowing of the existence of any noxious weeds on lands owned or controlled by him who fails to control such weeds in accordance with this
chapter, or who prevents or threatens to prevent entry upon land as provided in this chapter, or who interferes with the carrying out of the provisions of
this chapter, or who violates any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine not to exceed one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or up to one year in jail, or both such fine and imprisonment for each violation.
B. The director of agriculture, or the city weed superintendent, or the city fire chief may bring an action to enforce the provisions of this chapter and the
penalty provided for under this section.
C. 1. In addition to subsection A of this section, any person, firm, or corporation who owns or occupies any lot, tract, or parcel of land and fails to abate
within the time period required by the various sections of this code, after service of notice, shall be liable for a civil penalty in the amount of one
hundred dollars ($100.00).
2. If abatement of the same type of nuisance is required by the city a second time within the same season or calendar year as applicable, the owner or
occupant shall be liable for a civil penalty in the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00).
3. If abatement is required by the city a third time within the same season or calendar year as applicable, the owner or occupant shall be liable for a
civil penalty in the amount of three hundred dollars ($300.00). (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-8: NOTICES AND ORDERS OF WEED SUPERINTENDENT:
A. Commencement Of Proceedings: Whenever the weed superintendent or his representative has inspected or caused to be inspected any real property
and has found and determined that such real property has growing on it noxious weeds, he shall commence proceedings to cause eradication of the
same.
B. Notice And Order: The weed superintendent shall issue a notice and order directed to the owner of the real property. The notice and order shall contain:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 58/303
1. The street address and/or a legal description sufficient for identification of the premises upon which the noxious weeds are located.
2. A statement that the weed superintendent has found the real property to have located upon it noxious weeds.
3. A statement of the action required to be taken as determined by the weed superintendent. In the event the weed superintendent has determined that
the noxious weeds must be eradicated, the order shall require that the work physically commence within such time (not to exceed 10 working days
from the date of the order), and completed within such time as the weed superintendent shall determine is reasonable under all of the circumstances.
4. Statements advising that, if any required eradication work is not commenced within the time specified, the weed superintendent will proceed to
cause the work to be done and charge the cost, plus a civil penalty, as provided in section 4-4-7 of this chapter, thereof against the property or its
owner. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
5. Statements advising: a) that any person having any recorded title or legal interest in the real property may appeal from the notice and order of the
weed superintendent to the board of appeals, provided the appeal is made in writing as provided in this section and filed with the weed
superintendent within two (2) working days from the date of service of such notice and order; and b) that any person having any recorded title or
legal interest in the real property may appeal from the notice of abatement and eradication cost by the weed superintendent to the board of appeals,
provided the appeal is made in writing as provided in this section and filed with the weed superintendent within thirty (30) days from the date of
service of such notice and order; and c) that failure to appeal will constitute a waiver of all right to an administrative hearing and determination of the
matter. (Ord. 1274, 7-18-2012)
C. Service Of Notice And Order: The notice and order, and any amended or supplemental notice and order, shall be served upon the recorded owner.
D. Method Of Service: Service of the notice and order shall be made upon all persons entitled thereto either personally or by mailing a copy of such notice
and order by certified mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested, to each such person at his address as it appears on the last assessment role of
the county, or as known to the weed superintendent. If no address of any such person so appears, or is known to the weed superintendent, then a copy
of the notice and order shall be so mailed, addressed to such person, at the address of the real property involved in the proceedings. The failure of any
person to receive such notice shall not affect the validity of any proceedings taken under this section seven (7) days after date of mailing.
E. Proof Of Service: Proof of service of the notice and order shall be certified to at the time of service by a written declaration under penalty of perjury
executed by the person effecting service, declaring the time, date, and manner in which service was made. The declaration, together with any receipt
card returned in acknowledgment of receipt of certified mail shall be affixed to the copy of the notice and order retained by the weed superintendent.
(Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-9: APPEAL:
The procedures for appeal shall be analogous to those of section 4-4-6 of this chapter, as the same may be amended. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-10: PROCEDURE FOR CONDUCT OF HEARING APPEALS:
The procedures for appeal shall be analogous to those of section 4-4-6 of this chapter, as the same may be amended. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-11: ENFORCEMENT OF THE ORDER OF THE WEED SUPERINTENDENT OR THE BOARD OF APPEALS:
A. General Provisions: After any order of the weed superintendent or the board of appeals made pursuant to this chapter has become final, no person to
whom any such order is directed shall fail, neglect or refuse to obey such order. Any such person who fails to comply with such order is guilty of a
misdemeanor.
B. Failure To Obey Order: In the event, after any order of the weed superintendent or board of appeals made pursuant to this chapter has become final,
the person to whom such order is directed shall fail, neglect or refuse to obey such order, the weed superintendent may: 1) cause such person to be
prosecuted under subsection A of this section; or 2) institute any appropriate action to abate such real property as a public nuisance.
C. Failure To Commence Work: Whenever the required eradication work is not commenced within ten (10) days after any final notice and order issued
under this Chapter becomes effective, the Weed Superintendent may, in addition to any other remedy herein provided, cause the noxious weeds to be
eradicated. Any such eradication work shall be accomplished and the cost, along with civil penalty, as provided in Section 4-4-7 of this Chapter, thereof
paid and recovered in the manner hereinafter provided in this Chapter. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-12: PERFORMANCE OF WORK OF ERADICATION:
A. Procedure: When any work of eradication is to be done pursuant to this Chapter, the Weed Superintendent shall accomplish this work by use of City
personnel or by private contractor under the direction of the Weed Superintendent.
B. Cost: The cost of such eradication work, plus a civil penalty, as provided in Section 4-4-7 of this Chapter, may either be made a special assessment
against the property involved, or may be collected, along with costs and reasonable attorney fees, in a civil action. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-13: RECOVERY OF COSTS OF ERADICATION:
The Weed Superintendent shall, upon the completion of the work of eradication, file with the Clerk of the City a report specifying the work done, the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 59/303
itemized and total cost of the work, a description of the real property upon which the noxious weeds were located, and the name and address of the
person entitled to notice. The Clerk shall confirm the account and shall direct that the same be collected in any of the following ways:
A. Recovery Of Costs By Special Assessment:
1. The Council may cause the assessment to be recorded on the County assessment role. Thereafter such assessment shall constitute a special
assessment against and a lien upon the real property.
2. Immediately upon it being placed on the assessment role, the assessment shall be deemed to be complete, the amount assessed shall be payable,
and the assessment shall be a lien against the real property. The lien shall be subordinate to all existing special assessment liens previously
imposed upon the same property, and shall be paramount to all other liens except for State, County and property taxes upon which it shall be upon a
parity. The lien shall continue until the assessment and all interest due and payable thereon are paid.
3. All such assessments remaining unpaid after thirty (30) days from the date of recording on the assessment roles shall become delinquent and shall
bear interest at the rate of judgments in the State.
4. A certified copy of the assessment shall be filed with the County Auditor as required by law. The amount of the assessment shall be collected at the
same time in the same manner as ordinary property taxes are collected, and shall be subject to the same penalties and procedure and sale in case
of delinquency as provided for ordinary property taxes. All laws applicable to the levy, collection and enforcement of property taxes shall be
applicable to such assessment.
B. Recovery Of Costs By Civil Action:
1. The charge may be a personal obligation of the property owner, who shall be liable and responsible for payment of the same as a civil penalty, and
for payment of all fees, costs and attorney fees incurred in the collection of such civil penalty. The City shall be entitled to recover civil judgment from
a court of competent jurisdiction for the amount of the civil penalty and all costs and fees incurred by such civil action. Upon entry of judgment as
provided to any judgment holder under the provisions of Idaho law.
2. The City Council may direct the City Weed Superintendent to turn over the claim to a collection agency for collection, with the same powers as in
subsection B1 of this Section. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-1999)
4-4-14: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
Any and all ordinances of the City or portions thereof, found to be in conflict with the provisions of this Chapter are hereby repealed. (Ord. 1025, 7-21-
1999)
Chapter 5
RIFLE RANGES
4-5-1: CITY PROPERTY DESIGNATED FOR USE:
A parcel of real property belonging to and being the property of the City, and being hereinafter more particularly described, is hereby designated and
authorized for use as a gun shooting and firing range. The use of said property shall be so authorized, restricted and controlled for persons using said
property for the firing and shooting of any type of rifle, pistol, any firearm or projectile emitting pneumatic device.
Said property so designated as a gun firing and shooting range is more particularly described as follows: The part and portion of the North half of the
Southeast quarter of the Southwest quarter of Section 7, Township 57 North, Range 2 West, Boise Meridian, Bonner County, Idaho, and the North half of
the South half of the Southeast quarter of the Southwest quarter of Section 7, Township 57 North, Range 2 West, Boise Meridian, Bonner County, Idaho
developed as and marked, designated and signed as a rifle, pistol and firearm firing and shooting range. (Ord. 680, 9-20-1979; 1983 Code)
4-5-2: HOURS OF OPERATION:
No such use of the abovedescribed property shall be held before eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. nor later than one hour before sunset. (Ord. 680, 9-20-1979;
1983 Code)
4-5-3: PROHIBITION AGAINST INTOXICATING BEVERAGES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or consume beer or any other intoxicating beverage or to have in his possession any open bottle, can or other
container containing such beer or other intoxicating beverage while in or at said property above described or at any City-owned property immediately
adjacent to it, more particularly described as follows: Government lots 3 and 4, and the east half of the Southwest Quarter of Section 7 Township 57 North
Range 2 West Boise Meridian, Bonner County, Idaho. (Ord. 845, 7-20-1987)
4-5-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating the use of said property as above described or violating the permitted hours for said use shall, upon conviction, be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and subject to a fine not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00) or by imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months, or by both such fine
and imprisonment. (Ord. 680, 9-20-1979; 1983 Code)
