e. Any fencing shall be of at least 9-gauge chainlink fence. No other type of fencing shall be permitted. Fences shall be installed in such a manner as
to prevent animals from escaping by digging under or escaping over the top.
f. All kennels shall have natural lighting sufficient to comply with uniform building code requirements, or other uniform code standards applicable to
buildings subsequently adopted by the city for an R type structure. Adequate artificial lighting shall be provided in accordance with uniform
electrical code requirements, or other uniform electrical code standards subsequently adopted by the city for residential structures.
2. Commercial Indoor Housing Facilities: The indoor housing facilities for commercial kennels shall meet all the preceding requirements for
noncommercial facilities and shall also meet the following requirements:
a. All indoor facilities shall have three foot (3') high solid, nontransparent walls or partitions between pens.
b. All flooring shall slope at one-half inch (1/2") per running foot to prevent pooling of urine and cleaning solutions. Floors shall be of a smooth,
nonporous, nonwater permeable substance.
c. All indoor housing facilities will have sound degrading characteristics that will prevent long sound reverberation or sound reaching neighboring
locations.
d. All indoor housing facilities shall also have an external space for various breeds. All kennel runs shall provide the square footage per dog based
on the maximum weight of each dog as set forth previously herein.
3. Outdoor Housing Facilities: All outdoor housing facilities, commercial or noncommercial shall meet the following general requirements set forth as
follows:
a. Any outdoor housing facility shall be of sufficient structural strength and shall be maintained in good repair so as to protect the animals from injury,
to contain the animals and to restrict the entrance of another animal.
b. Outdoor housing facilities shall provide sufficient shade from the sun so as to prevent overheating or discomfort to the animals.
c. Outdoor housing facilities shall provide access to shelter to allow animals to remain dry during inclement weather.
d. Outdoor housing facilities shall provide shelters for all animals with sufficient clean bedding and other protection so as to protect the animal from
harm when the temperatures are below fifty degrees Fahrenheit (50°F).
e. Outdoor housing facilities shall provide a suitable method for elimination of urine and other liquid substances. Suitable provision shall be
equivalent to a two inch (2") layer of pea gravel over a large drain field of at least six inches (6") in depth. The large gravel drain field shall not be of
such depth that it penetrates through the topsoil on which it is constructed.
f. All outdoor facilities shall provide sufficient space in the enclosure and in the kennel house. Minimum space requirements are set out in the table
previously set forth herein. If a kennel enclosure or kennel contains more than one dog, the minimum number of square feet required is the sum of
the square feet requirements for each individual dog kept therein.
g. Any fencing shall be of at least 9-gauge chainlink fence. No other type of fencing shall be permitted. Fences shall be installed in such a manner as
to prevent animals from escaping by digging under or escaping over the top.
4. Feeding And Care Of Animals: All kennels whether commercial or noncommercial shall meet the following feeding and care requirements:
a. Animals shall be provided food which is free from contamination and is wholesome, palatable and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value so as to
meet the normal daily requirements for the condition and size of the animal.
b. Food receptacles shall be accessible to all animals and shall be located so as to minimize contamination by excreta. Feeding pans shall be
durable and shall be cleaned daily.
c. Clean potable water shall be available to the animals in conformance with the principles of good animal husbandry unless restricted for veterinary
care. Water receptacles shall be cleaned every day.
d. All food and bedding for the animals shall be kept in a storage area such that the food and bedding supplies are protected against infestation or
contamination by vermin.
e. Refrigeration shall be provided for any supplies of perishable food.
f. Each pen shall have a satisfactory bowl and bowl system for both food and water.
5. Sanitation Of Primary Facilities: All kennels whether commercial or noncommercial shall meet the following sanitation requirements:
Excreta shall be removed from each kennel enclosure and kennel house at least once daily to prevent contamination of the animals contained
therein and to reduce disease hazard and odors.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 78/303
a. Individual and subsurface disposal systems used to dispose of any kennel generated wastewater shall be reviewed by the Panhandle health
district:
(1) At the initial application for a kennel license; and
(2) At the discretion of the department at reasonable times.
Wastewater and subsurface sewage disposal system loading will be assessed for compliance with Idaho's rules and regulations for individual
and subsurface sewage disposal systems and Panhandle health district's environmental health code as well as ordinances and rules of the city
of Sandpoint applicable to waste disposal. On site dry wells must be registered with the department of water resources. Dry wells are not a
permitted wastewater disposal system.
b. Solid excreta, if removed from the said property, shall be double bagged and disposed of in such a manner as to prevent a public health hazard.
(1) Sanitizing: At least once each day each kennel enclosure shall be sanitized by washing with water and soap or detergent.
(2) Replacement Of Gravel: Pens using pea gravel or its equivalent shall be sanitized by removing the gravel and replacing it when it no longer
provides adequate sanitation so as to reduce disease hazard and odors.
(3) Vaccination: Each individual dog shall be vaccinated for rabies in accordance with this chapter.
(4) Records: The kennel operator shall keep available for inspection on the premises a record that shall show the name, current address and
telephone number of the owner of each animal being kept at the kennel, the description of the animal, including its age, breed, sex and color. As
a part of such record, a current valid rabies certificate or other written proof of vaccination, verified by phone, shall be maintained for each dog
required to be vaccinated by this chapter. In addition, each kennel operator shall have someone in attendance at the kennel who can identify
each animal in the kennel except that animals under six (6) months of age may be identified as to the litter.
(5) Pest Control: An effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, avian and mammalian pests shall be established and maintained.
6. Care And Treatment Of Sick And Injured Animals:
a. Isolation and quarantine areas shall be part of every commercial kennel facility to prevent physical contact by or between animals who are under
quarantine or treatment for a communicable disease. The facilities should protect from cross contamination by saliva, waste material or washing
solutions. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
b. Animals shall be separated according to the following standards. Commercial and noncommercial kennels shall meet these requirements:
(1) Females in estrus shall not be housed in the same kennel enclosure as males, except for the purposes of breeding;
(2) Any dangerous dog shall be housed individually in a separate kennel enclosure; (Ord. 1338, 11-16-2016)
(3) Puppies shall not be housed in the same kennel enclosure with any other adult dog other than their dam, except when the owner specifically
requests combined housing;
(4) Dogs shall not be housed in the same kennel enclosure with other species of animal.
7. Violation: In addition to the penalties set out in this chapter, any violation of this section shall be grounds for revocation of a kennel license.
8. Authority To Inspect: The animal control officer or any other person authorized by the department or city may inspect any licensed kennel at any
reasonable time with or without notice.
9. Fees: The fee for a commercial or noncommercial kennel license shall be set from time to time by resolution of city council.
10. Revocation Of Kennel License, Denial Of Permit:
a. A kennel permit may be revoked or application for kennel permit denied by the department when any of the following conditions are found to exist:
(1) Animals from such kennel are picked up running at large more than three (3) times in any twelve (12) month period;
(2) Failure to maintain a list of animals kept at the kennel;
(3) Keeping more than the approved number and type of animals at the kennel;
(4) Failure to allow access of an authorized officer to inspect the kennel facility;
(5) Failure to maintain the kennel in a clean and sanitary condition;
(6) Failure to maintain adequate shelter and protection from the weather;
(7) Failure to maintain adequate and approved ventilation;
(8) Overcrowding of animals;
(9) Quartering together of animals which are temperamentally unsuited or allowing animals to approach as near to each other as to cause the
animals to be abused or tormented;
(10) Excessive loud noise;
(11) Failure to adequately treat or have treated any diseased or injured animal or to segregate such diseased animal so as to prevent the spread of
disease to other animals;
(12) Any other violation of the kennel regulations set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
b. The department shall notify the applicant or license holder in writing prior to any revocation or denial. Upon notice, a kennel license holder or
applicant shall have thirty (30) days to correct any defect and to petition the department to contest such revocation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 79/303
c. Thirty (30) days after the notice of revocation or denial, if no petition has been filed with the department, the kennel permit shall be deemed
revoked or the application denied.
d. If a petition has been filed within thirty (30) days, the Hearing Board will be convened within thirty (30) days of the filing of the petition to decide
whether to uphold the revocation or denial of the permit. A person may reapply for a kennel permit after one year if the conditions warranting the
revocation or denial have been ameliorated. (Ord. 1356, 9-5-2018)
5-4-5: CONTROL PROVISIONS:
A. Animals Running At Large Prohibited:
1. Livestock Prohibited: Owners shall not be permitted to let their livestock run at large in the City at any time during the year; and it shall be unlawful
for any person to herd or drive any animal through the streets without having said animal under control by means of rope, strap or other device by
which it may be led, unless such animal is being driven in harness or hauled. This subsection shall not be applicable to dogs and cats.
2. Fowl Or Poultry Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to keep fowl or poultry unless such fowl or poultry are at all times kept upon his own
premises.
3. Leash Law: No dog, whether licensed or not, shall be, or remain upon any public street or alley within the City, or any public place therein, or upon
any premises other than the premises of the person who owns, harbors, keeps, possesses or has custodial care of the dog, unless the dog is
maintained on a "leash" as heretofore defined, with the following exceptions:
a. Police dogs, in connection with lawful police work, so long as under adequate voice or other control of an authorized law enforcement officer.
b. Any dog being used and trained for search and rescue operations, under such conditions as may be reasonably necessary in the particular
circumstances.
c. Any licensed dog at large on private property with the express permission of the owner of the property.
Injury to any person or animal or damage to any property by a dog while at large, whether licensed or not, shall be the full responsibility of the dog
owner or person or persons responsible for the dog when such damages were inflicted.
Any dog found in violation of this section shall constitute prima facie evidence that the owner of the animal is in violation of this section. (Ord. 1260,
12-21-2011)
4. Areas Where Dogs Prohibited: No person shall take or allow any dog, whether leashed or unleashed, on any public beach or public park within the
City except as herein provided. A maximum of three (3) dogs per handler shall be allowed in the following parks:
a. Lakeview Park, permitted on leash only. Dogs are excluded from: the children's playground area, within the fenced tennis courts, and within the
boundaries of the basketball court. Dogs are not allowed inside the fence at Memorial Field;
b. Hickory Park, permitted on leash only. Dogs are excluded from: inside the children's playground, within the boundaries of the basketball court and
within the boundaries of the skate feature; and
c. Humbird Mill Park, permitted with leashes recommended. (Ord. 1292, 12-18-2013)
5. Female Dogs In Season (Estrus): Dog owners shall securely confine their female dogs while in season within an enclosure so as to prevent the
attraction of male dogs.
6. Prosecution Of Dog Owners: Prosecution of owners of dogs running at large shall be in accordance with Idaho Code section 25-2805. (Ord. 1260,
12-21-2011)
B. Sanitation Responsibilities:
1. It shall be unlawful for an owner or any person having custody or control of any animal to fail to remove the fecal matter deposited by his/her animal
on public property or private property not belonging to the owner. Removal must be effected before the owner leaves the immediate area where the
fecal matter was deposited. The owner must dispose of the fecal matter in a sanitary manner by depositing the same in a trash receptacle.
2. It shall be unlawful for an owner or any person having custody or control of any animal to fail to have in his/her possession a plastic bag or other
equipment suitable to remove his/her animal's fecal matter when accompanied by said animal on public property or public easement.
3. Owners of service dogs, when under the control of the person with the disability, will be exempt from subsections B1 and B2 of this section, if
physically unable to comply.
4. A violation of these sanitation responsibilities shall constitute an infraction, with penalties and fines, as provided in Idaho Code section 18-113A.
C. Releasing Animals Within The City Limits: It shall be unlawful for any person to release or allow to escape from confinement any domestic or wild
animal within the City limits. This does not apply to house pet cats owned by City residents or feral cats released as part of a trap, neuter and release
program authorized by the City. (Ord. 1288, 9-4-2013)
5-4-6: DANGEROUS DOGS:
Proceedings against any dog which bites or physically attacks a person in the City shall be in accordance with Idaho Code section 25-2809 et seq., "Idaho
Dangerous and At Risk Dogs Act". (Ord. 1338, 11-16-2016)
5-4-7: INJURIES AND COMMUNICABLE DISEASE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 80/303
No person shall knowingly harbor or keep any animal with any serious injury, or inflicted with mange, ringworm, distemper or any contagious disease,
unless such animal is being given adequate treatment for such disease or injury. The department may take immediate possession of such animal not
being so treated, or not responding to such treatment, and immediately dispose of the animal unless the owner shall forthwith place such animal under the
control and treatment of a licensed veterinarian. The owner of such animal shall pay all fees and expenses related to veterinary care, including, but not
limited to, transportation, confinement, board, veterinary care and associated treatment. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-8: ANIMALS IN UNATTENDED VEHICLES:
No person shall leave an animal in any unattended vehicle without adequate ventilation, or in any manner as to subject the animal to extremes of
temperature which adversely affect the animal's health and welfare. Any person who leaves an unattended animal in an open vehicle and the animal is
harassing passersby may be cited as set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-9: INHUMANE TREATMENT AND ABANDONMENT OF ANIMALS:
No person shall treat an animal in a cruel or inhumane manner or willingly or negligently cause or permit any animal to suffer unnecessary torture or pain.
No person shall abandon any domestic animal without care on any public or private property. All animals shall be provided with appropriate nutritive foods
and shelter. Potable water must be available as prescribed by good husbandry standards. Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the release of feral cats
as part of a trap, neuter and release program authorized by the City. (Ord. 1288, 9-4-2013)
5-4-10: INTERFERING OR OBSTRUCTING AN ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER:
Any person who shall hinder, delay, interfere with or obstruct the animal control officer or any peace officer engaged in the capturing, securing or taking of
any animal, or who shall open or in any manner directly or indirectly aid, counsel, or advise the opening of any animal or shelter cage, ambulance, wagon
or other vehicle used for the collecting or conveying of animal to the animal shelter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-11: RESERVED:
(Ord. 1334, 9-21-2016)
5-4-12: IMPOUNDED ANIMALS:
A. Cause For Impoundment: The department may impound an animal for, but not limited to, the following circumstances: any released or escaped
domestic or wild animal, unlicensed dog, running at large, suspected exposure to rabies, animals being kept in unsafe or unsanitary conditions, or
lacking proper care, nutrition, or housing; declared a dangerous dog, or poses a serious harm or health risk to the public, an animal disturbing the
peace, or has injuries or a communicable disease, or for any other violation of this Code.
B. Notification: The department will notify the owner of the animal, if known, in person, by telephone, by depositing notice in the U.S. mail properly
addressed to the owner or last known address of the owner, or by posting a notice on the premises of the owner within five (5) days of an
impoundment.
C. Impoundment Procedures:
1. An animal impounded for a violation of this Code may be released to the owner upon compliance with Code requirements. Compliance must be met
within five (5) days. The owner of the animal is responsible for all expenses incurred by an impoundment.
2. The owner of an impounded animal shall have the right to file, within five (5) days after receiving notice, a written request for a hearing with the
Hearing Board to contest the impoundment. If no request for a hearing is received within the allotted time period, the department may humanely
destroy the animal. A hearing may not be requested for the following violations: running at large, disturbing the peace, or unlicensed. (Ord. 1356, 9-
5-2018)
D. Disposition: Any impounded animal shall be held for a minimum of five (5) working days. After five (5) working days have passed the animal becomes
the property of the City or its designee if the owner has not contacted the department. The City will determine the manner in which the animal will be
attended to. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-13: ABATEMENT:
A. Public Nuisance: Any animal that constitutes a public nuisance, or constitutes a hazard to the public health or safety, or as defined within this section,
may be abated.
B. Notice Of Abatement: In the event an animal constitutes a public nuisance as set forth above or if set forth elsewhere in this Code, the department may
issue notice of abatement to the owner of said animal. Such notice shall contain the dates and types of previous events constituting a basis for the
animal being a public nuisance. Such animal shall be removed from the City, or if not already impounded, relinquished to the City or its designee within
three (3) working days from the date of notification.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 81/303
C. Hearing On Abatement: The owner of an abated animal shall have the right to file, within five (5) days after receiving notice, a written request for a
hearing with the Hearing Board to contest the abatement.
D. Maintaining Public Nuisance: Any person who owns or keeps and permits to run loose at any time within the City an animal declared to be a public
nuisance as set forth in this chapter, and who shall fail, neglect or refuse to abate the nuisance by destroying the animal, or removing the animal from
the City, or by permanently confining the animal, whichever be necessary to the abatement of such nuisance, within twenty four (24) hours after notice
to do so shall be in violation of this Code. (Ord. 1356, 9-5-2018)
5-4-14: INHERENTLY DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
It shall be a violation of this chapter to possess any "inherently dangerous animal" as heretofore defined. Any such animal may be impounded by the
department and abated in conformance with this chapter. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-15: CONDITION OF PEN AND PREMISES:
It shall be unlawful for any owner to fail to keep the premises where animals are kept, free from offensive odors to the extent that such odors are disturbing
to nearby residents. It shall be unlawful to allow the premises where animals are kept to become unclean or a threat to the public health by failing to
diligently and systematically remove all animal feces from the premises. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-16: LIVESTOCK:
It shall be unlawful for any person within the limits of the City to keep or maintain any livestock except in conformity with zoning regulations and with the
following requirements:
A. All excreta from the animal shall be removed daily from any building or shelter in which the animal is kept, or from any yard or enclosure in which the
animal is permitted, and the same shall be buried in the ground or placed in a covered container. If placed in a covered container, subsequent and final
disposal thereof, if made in the City, shall be done by burying the same in the ground.
B. No livestock shall be kept or permitted in any building, shelter, yard or enclosure unless the same shall be at least one hundred fifty feet (150') from any
residence, street or highway in the City. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-17: IMPOUNDING OF LIVESTOCK:
If any livestock shall be found running at large contrary to the provisions of this chapter, an officer may impound and confine the same in a secure place or
other place provided for that purpose and such animal(s) impounded and confined shall not be released until the owner or person entitled to the livestock
comes into compliance with the code and pays all associated fees. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-18: NOTICE AND SALE OF IMPOUNDED LIVESTOCK:
If the owner of an animal does not pay the charges and lawfully take it away within five (5) days from the time it is taken into custody, the City may sell
such animal at public auction after having given at least five (5) days' notice of the time and place of such sale by publishing said notice in the official
newspaper of the City, as well as serving a copy of said notice upon the owner or possessor, if known, of said animal. Such animal may be redeemed at
any time before the date of sale by payment to the City of any fees, expenses and charges. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-19: FREEING IMPOUNDED LIVESTOCK PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to break open or in any manner, directly or indirectly, aid or assist in breaking open any pen or enclosure with intent of releasing any
livestock confined therein. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-20: PET STORES:
A. Licensing:
1. All pet store owners must obtain a pet store license from the City. The license application shall state the name and address of the owner, the location
of the pet store and the types and breeds of the animals to be kept. Pet store licenses shall be nontransferable, and shall be valid for one year from
the date of issuance. The cost for a license shall be set from time to time by resolution of the City Council. This license shall be in addition to the
business license issued by the City.
2. An authorized officer of the department or other person designated by the department or City shall inspect all prospective pet stores prior to granting
a license, and any application for a pet store license must include written approval from the inspecting person stating that the requirements in this
chapter are being met.
3. Any application for a pet store license must include written approval from the City Planning Department showing that the pet store is in compliance
with all requirements, standards and conditions established by the zoning ordinance of the City of Sandpoint.
4. Any application for a pet store license must include the name, address, and telephone number of a licensed veterinarian who will care for any
animals which become sick or injured while at the pet store.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 82/303
B. Requirements: As prescribed by animal husbandry practices, a pet store shall provide:
1. Adequate and species appropriate nutrition in sufficient quantities to meet each individual animal's requirements;
2. Clean fresh water in sufficient quantities to meet each individual animal's requirements; and
3. Disease free sanitary conditions within adequate enclosures.
C. Inspection Of Pet Stores: Pet stores may be inspected by the department at any time and the pet license can be suspended at any time if the facility is
not being maintained in accordance with this Code. The pet store shall have twenty four (24) hours to bring the pet store into compliance before the
license is revoked.
D. Revocation Of License: The Chief of Police may at any time recommend the revocation of any license issued under the terms of the foregoing
subsections and the Chief of Police may suspend such license by notice in writing whenever the licensee has violated the provisions of any law of the
State or ordinance of the City relating to the carrying on of the business named in such license.
E. Appeal: Whenever any license provided for herein is refused or revoked by the Chief of Police or other proper official duly empowered to do so, the
licensee may appeal to the City Council the notice of revocation or license refusal. Notice of appeal shall be in writing and delivered to the City Clerk
within five (5) days from the notice of refusal or revocation. The City Clerk shall fix the time of hearing of the appeal within fourteen (14) days, at which
hearing all parties interested shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard. The City Council's decision shall be final. (Ord. 1208, 5-20-2009)
5-4-21: FEEDING BIG GAME PROHIBITED:
No person shall knowingly and intentionally feed big game animals. Persons who fail to cease feeding big game animals within seven (7) days of receiving
written notice by a City official through personal delivery or certified mail shall be in violation of this section. (Ord. 1313, 5-20-2015)
5-4-22: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter, or fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter, is subject to a civil citation fee, which are
payable at the City cashier's office within thirty (30) days of receipt of the civil citation. Each day's continued violation may constitute a separate offense. All
civil citation fees shall be established by resolution adopted by the City Council. (Ord. 1356, 9-5-2018)
Chapter 5
ANIMALS
(Rep. by Ord. 1072, 10-17-2002)
Chapter 6
CURFEW
5-6-1: PURPOSE AND POLICY:
The Policy of the City is:
A. To protect children's health and welfare which includes their care, guidance and control;
B. Parents, guardians and/or other persons having legal custody are responsible for providing for the physical custody and control of the child and to
determine where and with whom the child shall live and to provide the child with care, education and discipline;
C. A child who is unaccompanied by an adult having custodial rights or an adult person designated by a person having custodial rights and who is found to
be on the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, places, buildings, place of amusement, eating places,
vacant lots and other locations unsupervised by such adult having the lawful authority to be at such place between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00)
midnight and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. is at a greater risk for injury, becoming a victim of a crime, being involved in criminal activity, being a danger to
persons or property or otherwise being subject to danger. (Ord. 940, 2-22-1994)
5-6-2: CHILD ON THE STREET AT NIGHT:
It is unlawful for any child being an individual who is under the age of eighteen (18) years of age to be upon any street, highway, road, alley, park,
playground or other public places or buildings, or places of amusement, eating establishments, vacant lots and/or any other place without being
accompanied by an adult having custodial rights or an adult person designated by the adult having custodial rights or an adult person designated by the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 83/303
adult having custodial rights of said child between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of the following day; provided,
that the provisions of this Section shall not apply in the following instances:
A. When the child is upon an emergency errand directed by his or her parent or guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of said
minor;
B. When the child is returning directly home from a school activity, school entertainment, school recreational activity or school dance;
C. When the child is either going to, or going from his or her place of residence to or from his or her place of lawful employment and/or is working at the
child's place of employment;
D. When the child is attending or travelling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights of free speech, freedom of
assembly or free exercise of religion;
E. When the child is in a motor vehicle with parental consent for normal travel with interstate travel through the City;
F. A minor who is married or who is on active duty in the Armed Services of the United States. (Ord. 940, 2-22-1994)
5-6-3: PERMITTING CHILD TO VIOLATE CURFEW:
It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other person having legal custody of a child or any adult person designated by the person having legal
custody of a child under the age of eighteen (18) years to permit and/or allow said child to be upon any public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks,
playgrounds or other public grounds, places, buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or other locations without having designated an
adult person or said parent, guardian or other legal custodian to be with and supervising said child between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight
and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of the following day, except in the circumstances set forth in subsections 5-6-2A through F of this Chapter. (Ord. 940, 2-22-
1994)
5-6-4: VIOLATION:
A violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter is a misdemeanor and punishable as a misdemeanor pursuant to the laws of the State. (Ord. 940, 2-22-
1994)
Chapter 7
FALSE ALARMS
5-7-1: PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVE:
A. This chapter is enacted for the purpose of increasing the efficiency of emergency service providers within the city. It provides that the city may collect
fees for emergency responses to false alarms as established by the city council by ordinance. This chapter provides specific regulations for alarm
companies and alarm users. This chapter is to encourage owners and fire and security alarm businesses to properly use and maintain the operational
effectiveness of fire and security alarm systems in order to improve the reliability of fire and security alarm systems and reduce or eliminate false fire
and security alarms and nuisance fire and security alarms.
B. This chapter governs fire and security alarm systems intended to summon fire and law enforcement department personnel, and requires registration,
assessment of fees for excessive false fire and security alarms and nuisance fire and/or security alarms, and provides procedures for repeat offenders.
(Ord. 1243, 8-18-2010)
5-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the following meanings:
ADOPTED CODE(S): Code adopted by the jurisdiction and in the absence of adopted code, the National Fire Protection Association national fire alarm
code 72 (NFPA 72) and the National Fire Protection Association life safety code 101 (NFPA 101), the National Fire Protection Association standard for the
installation of sprinkler systems (NFPA 13, 13D and 13R).
ALARM SYSTEM: A device or series of devices, including, but not limited to, hardwired systems and systems interconnected with a radio frequency
method such as cellular or private radio signals, which emit or transmit a remote or local audible, visual or electronic signal indicating an alarm condition
and intended to summon fire or police response. Alarm system does not include an alarm installed in a vehicle or on someone's person unless the vehicle
or the personal alarm is permanently located at a site.
ENFORCEMENT OFFICIAL: The fire and/or police chief or their designated representative.
FALSE ALARM: An alarm dispatch request to a law enforcement or fire agency, when the responding enforcement officer finds no evidence of a fire,
criminal offense or attempted criminal offense after having completed a timely investigation of the alarm site.
FEE: The assessment of a monetary charge payable to the city of Sandpoint authorized pursuant to this chapter, to defray the expenses of responding to a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 84/303
false fire or security alarm or nuisance fire or security alarm.
FIRE AND SECURITY ALARM BUSINESS: Any person or business engaged in installing, monitoring or maintaining a fire or security alarm in structures
within the city of Sandpoint.
MONITORED SYSTEM: The process by which a fire or security alarm business receives signals from a fire or security alarm system and notifies the
appropriate emergency forces.
NUISANCE FIRE OR SECURITY ALARM: The activation of any fire and/or security alarm system, which results in a response by the fire or police
department, caused by mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, lack of proper maintenance or any other response for which the fire or police
department personnel are unable to determine the apparent cause of the alarm activation.
OWNER: Any person who owns the premises in which a fire or security alarm system is installed or the person or persons who lease, operate, occupy or
manage the premises.
PREMISES: Any building, structure or combination of buildings and structures which serve as dwelling units such as single-family, multi-family or any other
area within a building, structure or combination thereof which is used for any purpose, wherein a fire or security alarm system is installed. (Ord. 1243, 8-
18-2010)
5-7-3: FIRE SYSTEMS; INSPECTION, TESTING AND MAINTENANCE:
The owner and/or occupant shall ensure that all fire alarm systems are inspected and tested at least once per year in accordance with adopted code.
The owner and/or occupant shall ensure that all fire alarm systems are periodically maintained per manufacturer specifications and adopted codes. (Ord.
1243, 8-18-2010)
5-7-4: FIRE ALARM ACTIVATION; RESPONSE:
A. The owner shall be responsible for the activation of a fire alarm system.
B. A response to the activation of a fire alarm system shall result when any officer or member of the fire department is dispatched to the premises where
the fire alarm system has been activated.
1. At the time of response, the enforcement official shall contact Bonner County 911 dispatch or the building/business owner, occupant or the
designated representative and shall require such person to respond to the premises.
2. In the event the fire alarm system is a monitored system, it is the responsibility of the company monitoring the fire alarm system to notify
building/business owner, occupant or the designated representative at the request of the enforcement official.
3. In the event the household fire alarm system is a monitored system, it is the responsibility of the fire alarm business to offer the owner/occupant the
option to verify the fire alarm signal before dispatch, as allowed by adopted code.
4. In the event the household fire alarm system is a monitored system, it is the responsibility of the fire alarm business to forward cancellation of a fire
alarm signal to the Bonner County 911 dispatch center, who will in turn notify the responding fire department unit of the cancellation notification.
C. The officer or member of the fire department who responded to said premises shall serve the owner/occupant or the designated representative with a
fire alarm activation report. (Ord. 1243, 8-18-2010)
5-7-5: NUISANCE FIRE ALARMS:
In the event the activation of a fire alarm system is deemed by the enforcement official to be a nuisance fire alarm, the owner shall be served with a fire
alarm activation report by an officer or member of the fire department, indicating that the activation was deemed to be the result of a nuisance fire alarm.
A. This shall require the owner to return a completed report of service/repair within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the fire alarm activation report to verify, to
the reasonable satisfaction of the enforcement official, that:
1. The fire alarm system has actually been examined by a qualified fire alarm technician; and
2. A bona fide attempt has been made to identify and correct any defect of design, installation or operation of the fire alarm system which was
identifiable as the cause of the nuisance fire alarm.
B. Failure to return a report of service/repair within said fifteen (15) day period, which is reasonably satisfactory to the enforcement official, shall result in
assessment against the owner/occupant or the designated representative of a fee pursuant to the fees established by resolution of the city council for
the nuisance fire alarm. (Ord. 1243, 8-18-2010)
5-7-6: SERVICE FEES:
A. All fees collected as a result of fire emergency response categories established by the city council by resolution shall be utilized for capital
improvements within the fire department as requested by the fire chief and approved by the city council. Examples of these capital improvements
include, but are not limited to: apparatus replacement programs, building and grounds purchases and improvements and other capital equipment
purchases.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 85/303
B. All fees collected as a result of security alarm response categories established by the city council by resolution shall be utilized for capital improvements
within the police department as requested by the police chief and approved by city council. Examples of these capital improvements include, but are
not limited to: equipment and fleet equipment replacement programs, building and grounds purchases and improvements and other capital equipment
purchases.
C. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any newly installed alarm system for a period of forty five (45) days from the date of installation, but shall
apply from and after the expiration of forty five (45) days. (Ord. 1243, 8-18-2010)
5-7-7: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF ALARM BUSINESSES AND USERS:
A. Duties Of Security Alarm User:
1. User shall maintain the premises and the alarm system in a manner that will minimize or eliminate false alarms, including periodic maintenance and
cleaning of the alarm system. The alarm user shall also make every reasonable effort to respond or cause a representative to respond to the alarm
system location within thirty (30) minutes when notified by the police department or alarm company to deactivate a malfunctioning alarm system. The
representative will provide access for the police department to the premises or provide alternative security for the premises.
2. User may advise the police department that no representative will be responding to the alarm site, however, failure of an alarm user or
representative thereof to respond to an alarm site may result in no further police intervention at the site and for the occurrence due to the failure of a
representative to respond.
3. User shall not manually activate an alarm for any reason other than an occurrence of an event that the alarm system was intended to report.
4. User will properly train their employees in the correct operation of the alarm system and will provide them with an operating sheet summarizing the
proper use of the alarm system, as well as the security system operating manual.
B. Duties Of Security Alarm Installation Company:
1. The security alarm installation company shall provide written and oral instructions to each of its alarm users in the proper use and operation of their
security alarm systems. Such instructions will specifically include all instructions necessary to turn the security alarm system on and off and to avoid
false alarms.
2. Upon enactment of this chapter, security alarm installation companies shall use only ANSI/SIA CP-01 listed alarm control panels on all new
installations and panel replacements or upgrades.
3. Security alarm installation companies shall not use automatic voice dialers.
4. Every alarm installation company shall provide the enforcement official with a customer list in a format acceptable to the enforcement official, upon
request, to assist the enforcement official with creating the law enforcement's tracking data. This requirement is contingent upon state or local law
that protects this customer information as confidential.
C. Duties Of Security Alarm Monitoring Company:
1. Report alarm signals by using telephone numbers designated by the enforcement official;
2. Verify every alarm signal, except a duress or holdup security alarm activation, before initiating a security alarm dispatch request;
3. Communicate security alarm dispatch request to the municipality in a manner and form determined by the enforcement official;
4. Communicate cancellations to the municipality in a manner and form determined by the enforcement official;
5. Ensure that all security alarm users of alarm systems equipped with a duress, holdup or panic alarm are given adequate training as to the proper use
of the duress, holdup or panic alarm;
6. Communicate any available information (north, south, front, back, floor, etc.) about the location on all alarm signals related to the security alarm
dispatch request;
7. Communicate nature of alarm (i.e., burglary, robbery, panic, duress, silent, audible, interior or perimeter);
8. After a security alarm dispatch request, promptly advise the law enforcement agency if the security alarm monitoring company knows that the alarm
user or the responder is on the way to the alarm site;
9. Attempt to contact the alarm user or responder within twenty four (24) hours via mail, fax, telephone or other electronic means when a security alarm
dispatch request is made; and
10. Upon the effective date hereof, security alarm monitoring companies must maintain for a period of at least one year from the date of the alarm
dispatch request, records relating to alarm dispatch requests. Records must include the name, address and telephone number of the alarm user, the
alarm system zone(s) activated, the time of alarm dispatch request and evidence of an attempt to verify. The enforcement official may request copies
of such records for individually named alarm users. If the request is made within sixty (60) days of an alarm dispatch request, the security alarm
monitoring company shall furnish requested records within three (3) business days of receiving the request. If the records are requested between
sixty (60) days to one year after an alarm dispatch request, the security alarm monitoring company shall furnish the requested records within thirty
(30) days of receiving the request.
11. Every alarm monitoring company shall provide the enforcement official with a customer list in a format acceptable to the enforcement official, upon
request, to assist the enforcement official with creating the law enforcement's tracking data. This requirement is contingent upon state or local law
that protects this customer information as confidential.
12. Alarm monitoring companies shall not use automatic voice dialers. (Ord. 1243, 8-18-2010)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 86/303
5-7-8: FEE SCHEDULE:
All fees for false alarms shall be established by resolution adopted by the city council. (Ord. 1243, 8-18-2010)
5-7-9: FEE APPEAL PROCESS:
A. Written Appeal: An aggrieved person may appeal the police or fire department's assessment of a fee to the enforcement official. The aggrieved person
shall file a written appeal to the enforcement official by stating the reasons for the appeal within ten (10) working days after receipt of notice of fee.
Upon verbal contact with the aggrieved person, the enforcement official may waive the written appeal and conduct the matter informally.
B. Enforcement Official Decision: If the enforcement official denies the appeal of the fee, the enforcement official shall send written notice of the action and
statement of the right to an appeal. The notice shall include the appropriate time frames and procedures to file an appeal of the enforcement official's
decision.
C. Appeal Of Enforcement Official Decision: Upon receipt of the enforcement official's denial, the aggrieved person may appeal the decision by filing a
written request for a review, setting forth the reasons for the appeal within ten (10) working days of the date of the notice from the enforcement official.
Such written request shall be filed with the city clerk.
D. Hearing Conducted By City Council: The city council shall conduct a formal hearing and consider evidence presented by any interested person(s). The
city council shall make a decision on the basis of the preponderance of evidence presented at the hearing. The city council must render a written
decision within five (5) working days after the appeal hearing is held. The city council may grant or deny the appeal. (Ord. 1274, 7-18-2012)
E. Special Rule For Public Schools, Government Institutions, Medical Facilities:
1. The fees for false alarms are waived for an alarm system at any public or private elementary or secondary school, government institution, or medical
facility. (Ord. 1243, 8-18-2010)
Title 6
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
Chapter 1
TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
6-1-1: IDAHO MOTOR VEHICLE LAWS ADOPTED:
A. It is hereby declared to be the intent of the Governing Body of the City to aid and assist, by whatever means possible, for the utmost consistency in
traffic regulation among and between agencies of Idaho having such jurisdiction. Toward that end, adoption of the Idaho Motor Vehicle Laws by the
cities of Idaho is a necessary means of assuring maximum uniformity within the State.
B. There is hereby adopted for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the use of all streets and public thoroughfares of the City that certain
code, identified as the Idaho Motor Vehicle Laws, more particularly title 49, Idaho Code, and as the same may hereafter be revised by the Idaho
Legislature. (Ord. 401, 1-11-1971; amd. 1983 Code)
6-1-2: DESIGNATION OF SPEED LIMITS:
Subject to the provisions of this chapter, and except in those instances where another speed is specified, it shall be prima facie lawful for the driver of a
vehicle to drive the same on the streets of the City at a speed not exceeding the following:
A. Twenty five (25) miles per hour in all business districts.
B. Twenty five (25) miles per hour in all residential districts. (1983 Code)
C. Twenty (20) miles per hour when passing any designated hospital zone or when passing any designated school zone, when said school is in session.
(Ord. 833, 9-15-1986)
6-1-3: TURNING MOVEMENTS RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful for any driver of any vehicle to turn said vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in a business district and
shall not upon any street so turn a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with any other traffic. Any person found in
violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00). (Ord. 720, 5-19-1980; amd. 1983 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 87/303
6-1-4: PARKING REGULATIONS:
6-1-4-1: PROHIBITED PARKING:
A. Idling Motor Vehicle: No driver of a motor vehicle shall leave the vehicle unattended upon any street or public place while running and unsecured.
B. Double Parking: Double parking shall not be permitted on any of the streets within the City unless the vehicle qualifies for an exemption.
C. Parking On Curbing: No vehicle shall be parked or stand on the sidewalk or on any portion of the curbing along any of the streets of the City.
D. Commercial Vehicle: No commercial vehicle over twenty two feet (22') in length shall be parked overnight on a street in any residentially zoned area of
the City.
E. All Night Parking: It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of any day on a street or
highway in areas where overnight parking is prohibited. A map of the Downtown Limited Parking Zone may be obtained from City Hall or on the City's
website.
F. Parking Of Trucks In Downtown Limited Parking Zone: Parking of trucks longer than twenty two feet (22') and/or truck trailers is hereby prohibited on
streets or public parking areas within the Downtown Limited Parking Zone. Recreational vehicles are not included in this limitation and may legally park
within the Downtown Limited Parking Zone.
G. Parking Limit: The area designated as the "Downtown Limited Parking Zone" is regulated by two (2), three (3) and four (4) hour parking limits on the
streets and a twenty four (24) hour limit within the City parking lots. The boundaries of the Downtown Limited Parking Zone shall be defined by
resolution adopted by the City Council. Monthly parking permits may be purchased at Sandpoint City Hall or online at the City's website. (Ord. 1352, 6-
6-2018)
6-1-4-2: COMPLIANCE WITH PARKING REGULATIONS:
A. Owner's Responsibility: The owner of every motor vehicle is deemed ultimately responsible for compliance with parking regulations of the City. It shall
be unlawful for the driver or owner of a vehicle to disobey:
1. Signage regulating the time or manner of parking;
2. Code requirements regarding the kind of vehicle permitted to park at any place; or
3. Any other parking restriction given by any sign, signal, stripe or line, erected or placed on the public streets or in public parking lots as authorized by
the City.
B. Regulation By City Council: The location, duration, terms and conditions of specially regulated parking areas upon the public streets or within public
parking lots may be established by resolution of the City Council. The provisions of special parking regulations shall be communicated by signage or by
pavement markings which provide notice to vehicle operators.
C. Stopping, Standing And Parking: No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or at the
direction of a public safety officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places:
1. On a sidewalk;
2. In front of a public or private driveway;
3. Within an intersection;
4. On a crosswalk;
5. Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection, unless otherwise indicated;
6. Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet (30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless
the traffic authority indicates a different length by signs or markings;
7. On a roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street;
8. Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway;
9. In an alley so as to hinder or block traffic;
10. In front of a mailbox in a manner that would prevent the distribution of mail by the United States Postal Service. Postal carriers must be able to
drive into and out of the delivery area without backing up;
11. In a parking space designated for handicapped parking except for a vehicle that is momentarily in the space for the purpose of allowing a
handicapped person to enter or leave the vehicle, unless the vehicle is displaying a special license of the handicapped, or official handicapped card
issued by the State, or an official temporary handicapped card issued by the State or another state;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 88/303
12. Upon any officially marked bicycle lane, bicycle path, footpath or other separate right-of-way specifically set aside for use by pedestrians or
nonmotorized vehicles except at an intersection or when entering or leaving a roadway at a driveway, private road or alley. This section shall not
apply to authorized emergency vehicles meeting the conditions specified in title 49 of the Idaho Code, or authorized maintenance and construction
vehicles while actually engaged in work upon a roadway or nonmotorized right-of-way; or City employees;
13. At any place where traffic control devices regulating stopping, standing, or parking are placed at the direction of the City Council by duly passed
resolution, to regulate the flow of traffic or to ensure the safety of motorists or pedestrians;
14. Facing against the flow of traffic;
15. Where prohibited by signs or painted red curbs;
16. With the vehicle's wheels more than eighteen inches (18") from the curb. (Ord. 1352, 6-6-2018)
6-1-4-3: PARKING AFTER SNOW HAS FALLEN:
A. Downtown Limited Parking Zone: Upon an accumulation of two inches (2") to four inches (4") of snow, at the discretion of the Public Works Director or
Streets Supervisor, snow plows will plow the snow from the curb line to the center of the roadway where it will be removed and hauled away. After
snow has been plowed from the curb line, depositing snow from sidewalks onto the roadway is prohibited. Depositing snow from parking areas and
alleyways onto the street is prohibited at all times. Parking is prohibited on the streets and in the City's three (3) downtown parking lots from 2:00 A.M. -
6:00 A.M. from November 1st through March 1st, unless posted otherwise.
B. Residential Streets: Upon an accumulation of two inches (2") to four inches (4") of snow, at the discretion of the Public Works Director or Streets
Supervisor, snow plows will plow residential streets. Snow will be plowed to each curb line.
C. Snow Removal Policy: The complete snow removal policy, together with the snow removal map, may be obtained from City Hall or online at the City's
website. (Ord. 1352, 6-6-2018)
6-1-4-4: EXEMPTIONS:
The following exemptions shall be made to the preceding three (3) sections:
A. Public safety vehicles while in the performance of official duties;
B. Business owners and contractors (parking trucks and equipment for construction) parked at locations for which they have been granted an
encroachment permit by the Public Works Department;
C. Delivery vehicles of any length may double park to actively load and unload when no alternative is available. (Ord. 1352, 6-6-2018)
6-1-4-5: PARKING DURING SNOW REMOVAL OPERATIONS:
See section 6-1-4-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 1177, 7-18-2007)
6-1-4-6: VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION AND IMPOUNDMENT:
A. Creation Of Scofflaw List: Parking services shall prepare the scofflaw list consisting of vehicle license plates and vehicle owners owning vehicles with
six (6) or more parking tickets unpaid more than forty five (45) days after their issuance. The scofflaw list shall be updated weekly or more often as
needed to remain current.
B. Fee To Cover Administrative Costs: There is a fee imposed upon the owner of every vehicle on the scofflaw list whose vehicle is immobilized or
impounded hereunder in an amount set by resolution of the City Council to cover the additional administrative costs of immobilization and/or
impoundment.
C. Notice:
1. Parking services shall give notice by first class mail to the last known registered owner of the vehicle, as disclosed by the vehicle license number and
as provided by the Idaho Department of Motor Vehicles or equivalent vehicle licensing agency of the State in which the vehicle is registered for each
vehicle on the scofflaw list, stating that the vehicle is on the scofflaw list; and
a. The date and the nature of each ticket overdue and the amount due on each;
b. The total amount currently due;
c. A specific deadline for response, no less than ten (10) days after the date of mailing;
d. That the owner shall, by said deadline, respond to the notice. Response shall be by paying the total amount due, scheduling a hearing with the
City Council, or by arranging a payment schedule with the City's contracted collection agency for payment of the total amount due; and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 89/303
e. That if the vehicle owner fails to respond within the prescribed time period, any vehicle with the listed vehicle license plate or any other vehicle of
that owner will be subject to immediate immobilization or impoundment, payment of the fees imposed under subsection B of this section and
payment of the costs of immobilization, towing and storage.
2. The notice required by this subsection C is sufficient if mailed to the address provided by the Idaho Department of Motor Vehicles; provided,
however, that if parking services, after exercising due diligence, fails to discover any mailing address, then notice is sufficient if it is posted on the
vehicle, or personally served on the vehicle owner or driver, or provided by any other means reasonably calculated to provide notice to vehicle owner
or driver.
3. If the vehicle owner or an agent of the owner pays the fines and fees, including the amount(s) specified in subsection B of this section, and all towing
and storage charges, if any, or schedules a hearing with the City Council, or arranges a payment plan through the City's contracted collection
agency, parking services shall remove the vehicle from the scofflaw list. If any parking ticket not included on the scofflaw list for which the owner is
liable becomes overdue before the owner or agent appears to pay or sets a hearing with the City Council, such subsequent tickets shall also be paid
or bond shall be posted therefor before the vehicle is removed from the scofflaw list.
4. The owner of a vehicle that is subject to the procedures of this section is entitled to a hearing by the City Council to contest the validity of the
immobilization, the impoundment and/or the amount of towing and storage charges.
5. Failure to appear for a scheduled hearing or to remain current and in good standing on any arranged payment plan with the City's contracted
collection agency will result in the vehicle returning to the scofflaw list and being subject to immediate immobilization.
D. Immobilization:
1. If the owner of a vehicle to whom notice has been sent fails to respond to the notice within the deadline therein specified by paying all fines, fees,
towing, storage and administrative charges then due, including, but not limited to, the amount(s) specified in subsection B of this section, or posting a
bond to cover such fines, fees and charges such that the vehicle can be removed from the scofflaw list, then, at the discretion of a commissioned
City officer, the vehicle may be immobilized by installing on the vehicle a device known as a "boot", which clamps and locks onto a wheel of the
vehicle and impedes movement of the vehicle.
2. The person installing the boot shall leave under the windshield wiper or otherwise attach to such vehicle a notice advising the owner that:
a. The vehicle has been immobilized by the City of Sandpoint for failure to pay six (6) or more uncontested parking tickets within forty five (45) days
of their issuance;
b. That release of the boot may be obtained by paying the fines, fees and civil penalties due;
c. That unless such payments are made within two (2) business days of the date of the notice, the vehicle will be impounded; and
d. That it is unlawful for any person to remove or attempt to remove the boot, to damage the boot, or to move the vehicle with the boot attached.
3. No parking restriction otherwise applicable to the vehicle applies while the vehicle is immobilized by a boot installed under the provisions of this
section.
4. Before the vehicle may be released from immobilization, the vehicle owner or an agent of the owner shall:
a. Pay all fines and fees and charges then due, or
b. Post a bond to cover such fines, fees, and charges, or
c. Arrange any combination of payment and bond to cover the total due.
Upon payment, the vehicle shall be removed from the scofflaw list, and the boot shall promptly be removed from the vehicle. If any parking ticket
not included on the scofflaw list for which the owner is liable becomes overdue before the owner or agent pays, the subsequent tickets shall also
be paid before the vehicle may be removed from the scofflaw list or released from immobilization.
E. Impoundment:
1. At the discretion of a commissioned City officer, the following vehicles may be impounded:
a. A vehicle that was immobilized pursuant to subsection D of this section and the vehicle's owner failed to pay all fines, fees, and administrative
charges or post a bond to cover such fines, fees and charges within two (2) business days of the date the vehicle was immobilized; or
b. As otherwise authorized by the Idaho Motor Vehicle Laws as adopted by reference in section 6-1-1 of this chapter.
2. If a vehicle has been impounded as provided herein, before the vehicle may be released from impound, the vehicle owner or an agent of the owner
shall pay all fines and fees then owing, and all towing and vehicle storage charges. Upon such payment, the vehicle and owner shall be removed
from the scofflaw list. If any parking ticket not included on the scofflaw list for which the owner is liable becomes overdue before the owner or agent
pays, such subsequent tickets shall also be paid before the vehicle may be removed from the scofflaw list or released from impoundment. (Ord.
1328, 7-6-2016)
6-1-4-7: FEES FOR VIOLATIONS OF PARKING REGULATIONS:
Fees for violations of parking regulations shall be set by resolution adopted by the City Council. (Ord. 968, 3-20-1995)
6-1-4-8: CIVIL PENALTY:
The operator or registered owner of each motor vehicle found to be parked in violation of this chapter and upon notice of violation as herein set forth shall
pay a fee as set by resolution adopted by the City Council. Upon nonpayment of said fee, any registered owner or operator of a vehicle shall be liable and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 90/303
responsible for payment of all fees, costs and attorney fees incurred in the collection of such fees as a civil penalty for which the City shall be entitled to
recover civil judgment from a court of competent jurisdiction. Upon entry of judgment, the City shall have each, every, and all rights of enforcement of that
judgment as provided to any judgment holder by the provision of Idaho Code. (Ord. 968, 3-20-1995)
6-1-4-9: IMPOUND VEHICLES:
A. Any officer, upon discovery of a vehicle reported as stolen and not recovered, or any vehicle involved in any extraordinary circumstances, may take the
vehicle into custody and cause it to be taken to and stored in a suitable place, or may cause the vehicle to be placed in the custody of a tow truck
operator, all expenses of towing and storage to be those of the vehicle owner.
B. "Extraordinary circumstances" means any situation where an emergency exists or public safety is endangered, and any situation in which a vehicle: 1)
is blocking or impeding traffic; 2) is causing a hazard; 3) has the potential of impeding any emergency vehicles; 4) is impeding any snow removal or
other road maintenance operation; or 5) is not registered, or displays a license plate registration tag which has been expired for a period in excess of
thirty (30) days. (Ord. 968, 3-20-1995)
6-1-4-10: TEMPORARY NO PARKING ZONES; BARRICADES AND SIGNS; AUTHORITY; TOWING:
The City may establish temporary no parking zones to prevent the parking of vehicles on any street or portion of such street. The City may do so either by
placing appropriate signs or placing barricades or public safety officers at such places. It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle at such time and at
such designated places. Illegally parked vehicles may be removed and stored at the owners cost and expense. (Ord. 1352, 6-6-2018)
6-1-5: ONE-WAY STREETS DESIGNATED:
South Huron Avenue and Lakeview Boulevard are public streets within the City and that portion of South Huron Avenue and Lakeview Boulevard between
Antone Avenue and Euclid Avenue is hereby designated a one-way street only. The direction of travel on the above described portion of South Huron
Avenue and Lakeview Boulevard shall proceed in one-way directional traffic only from Antone Street to Euclid Avenue.
Portions of Pine Street and Main Street are hereby designated as one-way streets. Those portions designated for one-way and direction of travel shall be
as follows:
Eastbound on Pine Street from Fifth Avenue to Fourth Avenue.
Eastbound on Main Street from Fifth Avenue to Third Avenue.
Westbound on Main Street from Sixth Avenue to Boyer Avenue. (Ord. 1352, 6-6-2018)
6-1-6: "BIKE" PATHS OR TRAILS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle on any area designated as a "bike" path or trail. Such areas are restricted for bicycles and
pedestrian travel only. (1983 Code)
6-1-7: CARELESS DRIVING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in a careless manner or to drive carelessly as hereinafter defined and set forth over or along
any public street, alley, or public right-of-way within the City. For the purpose of this section and its enforcement to "operate in a careless manner or drive
carelessly" shall be construed to mean the operation of a motor vehicle without that degree of care commonly exercised by a reasonable and prudent
driver under like or similar circumstances and the same shall include, but not be limited to, the following specific acts of careless operation:
A. Starting or operating a motor vehicle in such manner as to cause the wheels to spin with sufficient force to throw gravel or other road surface material
from under such wheels so as to endanger or be likely to endanger persons or property.
B. Starting, stopping or operating a motor vehicle in such manner as to leave rubber marks on the roadway.
C. Failure to reduce speed to appropriate speed below twenty five (25) miles per hour when driving in a residential district where children can be seen
playing or are known to be playing.
D. Operating a motor vehicle in such manner as indicates the driver thereof is not in complete control thereof at all times.
E. Operating a motor vehicle when the physical and mental condition of the driver thereof is such that he cannot maintain safe and complete control of
such vehicle.
F. Failing to pay attention to the duties pertinent to the safe operation of any motor vehicle.
G. Failure to reduce speed to reasonable and prudent speed when roadway is icy, slick or wet or when other weather or road conditions require a
reduction in speed.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 91/303
Any person found in violation of this section, upon conviction, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 721, 5-19-1980; amd. 1983 Code)
6-1-8: CLINGING TO VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person riding upon a bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled or toy vehicle to attach the same or himself to any vehicle upon a
roadway. (1958 Code)
6-1-9: RAILROAD TRAINS BLOCKING STREETS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train to direct the operation of or to operate the same in such manner as to
prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period of time longer than ten (10) minutes, except that this provision shall not apply to trains or
cars in motion other than those engaged in switching. (1958 Code)

6-1-14: AIR COMPRESSION BRAKES:
A. The use of air compression brakes, otherwise known as "jake brakes", by any truck operator/driver within the City of Sandpoint is hereby prohibited and
shall be unlawful except under circumstances where the use of air compression brakes is necessary to prevent an accident or injury to persons or
property. (Ord. 1100, 1-21-2004)
B. The penalty for the use of unmuffled air compression brakes within the City limits of the City of Sandpoint shall be an infraction with penalties and fines,
as provided in Idaho Code section 18-113A. (Ord. 1352, 6-6-2018)
6-1-15: MOTORIZED SCOOTERS, KARTS AND HUMAN TRANSPORTERS:
The use of gas or electric powered motorized scooters, karts, and human transporters on City property is hereby regulated as follows:
A. May be used on streets, roads, alleys and other public rights-of-way if the gas or electric powered motorized scooter, kart, or human transporter is
licensed as a vehicle by the State of Idaho and the driver is a licensed driver by the State of Idaho (or any other state).
B. Use is prohibited on sidewalks, bike paths, bike lanes, parks, town square and other City property unless authorized and permitted by the City Council
with signs erected by the City to give notice of such allowed use.
C. The use of such equipment on private property with the permission of the owner is permitted provided that the noise from such machine does not
disturb other persons, in which case such use will constitute a nuisance.
D. This section shall not be construed to apply to motorized wheelchairs operated by a handicapped individual. (Ord. 1110, 4-21-2004)
E. Any violation of this section shall be an infraction with penalties and fines, as provided in Idaho Code section 18-113A. (Ord. 1352, 6-6-2018)
Chapter 2
NONMETERED PARKING REGULATIONS
6-2-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the NONMETERED PARKING REGULATION CHAPTER. (Ord. 824, 4-21-1986)
6-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
ROADWAY: That portion of a street between the regularly established curb lines.
SIDEWALK: That portion of a street between the curb lines and the adjacent property lines.
STREET: Every way set apart for public travel except alleyways, bridle paths, bicycle paths and footpaths.
VEHICLE: A conveyance propelled by motor power. (Ord. 824, 4-21-1986)
6-2-3: DOWNTOWN LIMITED PARKING ZONE:
The "Downtown Limited Parking Zone" shall mean nonmetered zones within which the parking of vehicles shall be allowed, controlled, regulated and
inspected by marking or recording methods. The Downtown Limited Parking Zone established for the purposes of this chapter and the areas where
limitations apply shall be described by resolution adopted by the City Council. (Ord. 1177, 7-18-2007)
6-2-4: SIGNS:
The City of Sandpoint has the responsibility for installing traffic control signs in the Downtown Limited Parking Zone established by resolution of the
Governing Body, for the purpose of giving notification of the maximum time for parking and other traffic and parking regulations in the Downtown Limited
Parking Zone. (Ord. 1177, 7-18-2007)
6-2-5: TIME LIMIT:
The maximum time limit permitted for parking in the downtown parking zones shall be two (2) hours, three (3) hours or four (4) hours per the parking signs
on the streets, and up to twenty four (24) hours in the three (3) City parking lots. The free City parking lots are designated as the ITD parking lot - West of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 93/303
5th Avenue, the downtown City parking lot - on 3rd Avenue between Church and Oak Streets; and the Sand Creek parking lot - off Bridge Street across
Sand Creek from downtown. (Ord. 1352, 6-6-2018)
6-2-6: VIOLATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, or to permit any vehicle registered in the name of, or operated by, such person to be parked at a location in the
Downtown Limited Parking Zone, including the City parking lots, in violation of the provisions of this chapter or any Municipal signs restricting parking.
No person shall remove, obstruct, and/or in any manner destroy the parking marks upon the tires of cars, which marks have been placed by person(s)
authorized by City to keep track of the length of time vehicles are parked. The first violation shall be an infraction punishable by a fine of one hundred
dollars ($100.00). A new or subsequent violation may be charged as a misdemeanor with the maximum penalty as provided in section 1-4-1 of this Code.
(Ord. 1309, 12-3-2014)
6-2-7: RECORD OF VIOLATIONS:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police, under the direction of the Governing Body, to keep account of all violations of this section. He shall cause to be
kept an account of and report each vehicle occupying a parking location in the Downtown Limited Parking Zone that is or has been parked in violation of
any of the provisions of this section, the date and hour of such violation, the make and the state license number of such vehicle and any other facts, a
knowledge of which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. (Ord. 1177, 7-18-2007)
6-2-8: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
The Chief of Police shall cause to be attached to such vehicle a notice stating that it has been parked in violation of this chapter and instructing the owner
or operator to report to the City Treasurer or his duly authorized deputy and pay in full satisfaction of such violation a fee set by resolution adopted by the
City Council. (Ord. 824, 4-21-1986)
6-2-9: EXEMPTIONS; HANDICAPPED PARKING:
Those vehicles bearing valid and current license plates and bearing the official handicapped insignia and symbol on the license plate shall be exempted
from the time restrictions as provided in Idaho Code 49-213. Those vehicles bearing valid and current license plates and designated "DV" only are entitled
to park within a space for a period not to exceed the maximum two (2) hour time limit. Nothing herein shall authorize, except, exempt or permit any vehicle
to park in a "no parking zone" or other restricted parking areas. (Ord. 824, 4-21-1986)
6-2-10: RESPONSIBILITY OF REGISTERED OWNER:
Every person in whose name a vehicle is registered shall be responsible for any violation of this chapter for over parking or unlawful parking caused by the
parking of said vehicle in violation hereof. It shall be no defense that the vehicle was parked illegally or over parked by another unless proof is presented
that said vehicle had been stolen and had not been returned to the registered owner by the date of the violation. (Ord. 824, 4-21-1986)
6-2-11: OVER PARKING FEES:
Over parking fees shall be set by resolution adopted by the City Council. (Ord. 969, 3-20-1995)
6-2-12: CIVIL PENALTY:
The operator or registered owner of each motor vehicle found to be overparked in violation of this chapter and upon notice of violation as herein set forth
shall pay a parking fee as set by resolution adopted by the City Council. Upon nonpayment of said parking fee, any registered owner or operator of a
vehicle shall be liable and responsible for payment of all fees, costs and attorney fees incurred in the collection of such fees as a civil penalty for which the
City shall be entitled to recover civil judgment from a court of competent jurisdiction. Upon entry of judgment, the City shall have each, every, and all rights
of enforcement of that judgment as provided to any judgment holder by the provision of Idaho Code. (Ord. 969, 3-20-1995)
6-2-13: CRIMINAL PENALTY:
Any parking violation that is unpaid or contested, or where more than three (3) violations occur in any one month, may be prosecuted as an infraction with
a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). Such penalty shall be in addition to any civil penalty imposed. (Ord. 1151, 6-21-2006)
Chapter 3
ABANDONED, WRECKED VEHICLES
6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=437 94/303
ABANDONED MOTOR VEHICLE OR OTHER PERSONAL PROPERTY: An automobile or personal property which remains upon the street or other public
property for a period of time longer than forty eight (48) hours, the owner of which cannot be located or the owner refuses to remove the same.
STOLEN MOTOR VEHICLE OR OTHER PERSONAL PROPERTY: That property which the Police Department has reasonable grounds to believe to be
stolen.
UNIDENTIFIED MOTOR VEHICLE OR OTHER PERSONAL PROPERTY: Such motor vehicles or other personal property where ownership thereof cannot
be ascertained. (Revised Code 1958)
6-3-2: REMOVAL OF UNIDENTIFIED, STOLEN, WRECKED OR ABANDONED VEHICLES; CHARGES:
A. It shall be unlawful for any owner or any person in charge of a motor vehicle or other personal property to leave or abandon the same upon the streets
or public places.
B. The Police Department is hereby authorized, in addition to any penalty that may be provided therefor, to remove an unidentified, stolen, wrecked or
abandoned motor vehicle or other personal property as herein defined, found upon any public thoroughfare or other property of the City and shall keep
the same in its custody and control at such place as may be designated by said Police Department until redeemed by the owner; and all such
unidentified, stolen, wrecked or abandoned motor vehicles or other personal property which now is in the possession of the Police Department shall be
subject to the actual cost of removal or tow-in from the public place and the storage charge as long as the same is in possession and custody. (Revised
Code 1958)
